headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: We can.
componenttext: We can.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on brand Dr Pepper, the past few quarters, you guys have been, at least from my perspective, more confident in that trademark in the trends there, including on the diet side. And especially Q4 heading into the heart of college football season, through
componenttext: So on brand Dr Pepper, the past few quarters, you guys have been, at least from my perspective, more confident in that trademark in the trends there, including on the diet side. And especially Q4 heading into the heart of college football season, through that lens, that negative 2% volume number looks a bit disappointing, even acknowledging the fountain promotion that you were cycling. And I guess your perspective on that will be great. Do you agree with that? Is it modestly disappointing? And how do you think about that trademark heading into and through '16?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we still look at it, Steve. We're outperforming the category. So I mean, we're -- we'll always have lots of programs behind Dr Pepper. College football is phenomenal. I mean, part of college football came into Q3 and Q4, the way it laid out there. W
componenttext: Well, we still look at it, Steve. We're outperforming the category. So I mean, we're -- we'll always have lots of programs behind Dr Pepper. College football is phenomenal. I mean, part of college football came into Q3 and Q4, the way it laid out there. We had tremendous upside in the first half of the college football. We still had growth through the total program. But as we factored in the diets and we had the fountain, large promotional activity and new availability on fountain a year ago, we're still very pleased with where Dr Pepper is at and where our plans are for taking it in 2016. You've heard some of the programs we had out there with it. Our bottlers are committed, excited about the brand. It continues to be a big contributor for them. So we're very pleased.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay. And I guess a question, if I could, on the cash return strategy. And maybe the answer is embedded in your response to Bill's earlier question. But you talked in the past about striking a balance between the dividend increase and share buybacks
componenttext: Okay, okay. And I guess a question, if I could, on the cash return strategy. And maybe the answer is embedded in your response to Bill's earlier question. But you talked in the past about striking a balance between the dividend increase and share buybacks and I appreciate you’re doing both in 2016. But the 10% dividend increase really doesn't move the needle too much on your payout ratio, which is still below peers. And it seems just out of balance with the essentially 30% increase in buybacks at the midpoint in terms of striking that balance when the multiple in your stock is essentially at an all-time-high level. So can you give us some insight into your thinking there in terms of what you recommend to the board? And maybe the answer is that $250 million debt finance step-up is kind of onetime and it rolls back off. But just how do we think about you striking a balance between what right now seems like an imbalanced strategy for 2016?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay Steve. Thanks. It's Marty. Listen, so the $250 million, that is onetime, right? We're not -- so the imbalance, as you call it, between more share repurchases in 2016 is simply the onetime $250 million. Otherwise, expect to see our distributions come
componenttext: Okay Steve. Thanks. It's Marty. Listen, so the $250 million, that is onetime, right? We're not -- so the imbalance, as you call it, between more share repurchases in 2016 is simply the onetime $250 million. Otherwise, expect to see our distributions come out of free cash flow and not through incremental borrowings to lever up to distribute. The 50-50 balance between -- the roughly 50-50 balance between share repurchases and dividends is where we've been. I know I've communicated to many of you that if we were going to lean one way or the other, probably, we would go more heavily into the dividend. And maybe one day we will, but as we go out and talk to shareholders, Steve, they -- most of them are satisfied with this. So we didn't see the need to do anything much different. We simply, as you said, raised it on an equivalent basis with this year's EPS growth rate, that kept the payout ratio more or less the same.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if I could -- just one more thing. I don't want to belabor the point too much, but going back to Ali's question on the allied brands. I mean, do you think we should treat all profit dollars the same when looking and valuing your overall business
componenttext: Okay. And if I could -- just one more thing. I don't want to belabor the point too much, but going back to Ali's question on the allied brands. I mean, do you think we should treat all profit dollars the same when looking and valuing your overall business? Or is there inherently more risk attached to those brands that you yourselves do not own? It seemed from your prior answer that maybe the answer is yes. So I just wanted to kind of give you a chance to expand on that.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, here's what I would tell you. I understand the nature of that question. I'll tell you that the other day, I was looking down the opportunities of people that we're at some stage of discussion with. There are 25 companies, at least, on that list. So
componenttext: Steve, here's what I would tell you. I understand the nature of that question. I'll tell you that the other day, I was looking down the opportunities of people that we're at some stage of discussion with. There are 25 companies, at least, on that list. So there's a lot happening in the beverage space. All of you see it when you go into stores, you see what's on the shelf, you see these niche products. So I said earlier, maybe we'll lose some at some point, but we'll also gain. And so the question is what's the best position for us, in our view, to capture LRB growth? But not CSD growth, LRB growth. Both through better execution in our core, which is what we're showing each and every period -- Larry talked about a few of the accomplishment. There's opportunity there in our core, and then capturing these growing categories by partnering with people that have a lot of passion, energy, credibility, financing associated with them. And I would tell you that the allied brand portfolio might be different 10 years from now in terms of what's in there than in today, but I guarantee you, it'll be a lot bigger.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Judy Hong with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Judy Hong with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a couple of questions from my end. First, just in terms of the price mix outlook for 2016, it sounds like you're embedding both the concentrate price increases and then a little bit of the rate increases on the Warehouse delivery business. So I know fr
componenttext: So a couple of questions from my end. First, just in terms of the price mix outlook for 2016, it sounds like you're embedding both the concentrate price increases and then a little bit of the rate increases on the Warehouse delivery business. So I know from -- at the start of last year, you were a little bit cautious on maybe taking some rate increases. But can you just talk about how you feel about the ability to sort of take pricing? And how much of the focus on the smaller pack sizes, also, do you think that will contribute to the mix component of that in 2016?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Marty, the concentrate price increase is already in effect. And that's worth, spread across the entire company, 40 basis points. The Warehouse Direct pricing actions I referred to, those are already been communicated to customers and those are alread
componenttext: It's Marty, the concentrate price increase is already in effect. And that's worth, spread across the entire company, 40 basis points. The Warehouse Direct pricing actions I referred to, those are already been communicated to customers and those are already in effect. And as I said earlier, we've made no assumption on any absolute pricing in CSDs. So to the extent that, that happens in the marketplace, as we've done in the past, we will take advantage. That would be upside to us. Package mix continues to shift. We too, are shifting to smaller cans in our own system. Larry mentioned it. We're rolling that out now. We've got the capability in a few of our plants, with some of our plants coming up, the remaining part of our network where we're going to do this coming up, through the first half of the year primarily. And that will contribute -- we haven't disclosed on a package mix basis what's -- what that is worth. Allied brands, of course, that -- they -- just because they're higher-revenue cases, as you model your top lines, of course, those are going to be positive in terms of rate per case. But we've -- I want to be clear, the pricing assumptions that we have embedded, the absolute pricing is already in place.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay. And then, Marty, just on the FX side. So can you just remind us of your transaction exposure there? Because it sounds like '16, maybe it's a little bit more of a transaction headwind than I think what we were modeling.
componenttext: Got it. Okay. And then, Marty, just on the FX side. So can you just remind us of your transaction exposure there? Because it sounds like '16, maybe it's a little bit more of a transaction headwind than I think what we were modeling.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The $0.18 is worth about now $47 million, $48 million on a before tax basis. You're going to have about $28 million of that, I believe, is going to be transaction and $19 million translation, okay, at the operating line -- at the operating income lin
componenttext: Yes. The $0.18 is worth about now $47 million, $48 million on a before tax basis. You're going to have about $28 million of that, I believe, is going to be transaction and $19 million translation, okay, at the operating line -- at the operating income line.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And what's exposure just in terms of transaction cost [ph]?
componenttext: And what's exposure just in terms of transaction cost [ph]?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So transaction, the key exposures are when you go to Canada and you look at our WD business, whether it's Hawaiian Punch, Clamato, et cetera, all those products are manufactured in the United States. So we have a currency transaction risk there between th
componenttext: So transaction, the key exposures are when you go to Canada and you look at our WD business, whether it's Hawaiian Punch, Clamato, et cetera, all those products are manufactured in the United States. So we have a currency transaction risk there between the sourcing currency and the selling currency. And the big transaction exposure for Mexico, as you know, the industry in Mexico is predominantly a bottle business, not a can business. And the price of resin, which is oil-denominated, is U.S. dollar priced.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, okay. And then just lastly, on commodities, how much are you hedged at this point in terms of '16 exposure?
componenttext: Got it, okay. And then just lastly, on commodities, how much are you hedged at this point in terms of '16 exposure?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're roughly 3/4 covered. And if you were to look at it rolling out through the year, you'd find lots of coverage in Q1, about 90%. By the time you get out to the fourth quarter, as we sit today, we're down to 30%. So we have open opportunities later in
componenttext: We're roughly 3/4 covered. And if you were to look at it rolling out through the year, you'd find lots of coverage in Q1, about 90%. By the time you get out to the fourth quarter, as we sit today, we're down to 30%. So we have open opportunities later in the year.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Mark Swartzberg with Stifel Nicolaus.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Mark Swartzberg with Stifel Nicolaus.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had 2 questions. I guess one is on 7UP, which isn't the most obvious choice from where I sit for getting this lean track focus in the sense that it seems to have some velocity issues. And I know you've struggled to try to reposition the brand. So could
componenttext: I had 2 questions. I guess one is on 7UP, which isn't the most obvious choice from where I sit for getting this lean track focus in the sense that it seems to have some velocity issues. And I know you've struggled to try to reposition the brand. So could you talk a little bit about the health of the brand from a consumer standpoint? And then why, in fact, it is getting this kind of relative focus in terms of filling those distribution voids?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, absolutely. I mean, that's -- to your point on the velocity, that's the main reason we're doing it. As we go across our organization, especially Rodger's packaged beverage on the DSD side, I mean, it's the biggest brand a lot of guys have. It's thei
componenttext: Well, absolutely. I mean, that's -- to your point on the velocity, that's the main reason we're doing it. As we go across our organization, especially Rodger's packaged beverage on the DSD side, I mean, it's the biggest brand a lot of guys have. It's their lead brand. The category, the lemon lime category, has struggled somewhat. But we will -- we got the organization as a whole looking at it saying, "Let's get behind our brand. Let's figure out what we're doing right, what we're doing wrong, and let's get a lean track in place." And listen, the name's on our buildings in a lot of these locations, and we want to see that brand growing. And so we've got some of our top people, some of our veterans that have been around for a long time that love that brand. And we're going to grow it and figure out what we're going to do for the long term.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: But where I'm coming from is -- and it's great to hear the focus. But where I'm coming from is that there's a pull issue there. So part of the pull, I appreciate, is a function of seeing more -- it becoming more visible to folks as they walk in and out of
componenttext: But where I'm coming from is -- and it's great to hear the focus. But where I'm coming from is that there's a pull issue there. So part of the pull, I appreciate, is a function of seeing more -- it becoming more visible to folks as they walk in and out of a store. But there seems to still be a more fundamental issue with the brand. So can you talk about what your research actually says about the health of the brand? And for that matter, how important simply added facings is to the health of the brand.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: It will be -- that will be part of the entire program. You're exactly right. I mean, we've got to figure out the pull, the guys in field will solve for the push. We're going to get it in the back door, now what we going to do to get it out the front door.
componenttext: It will be -- that will be part of the entire program. You're exactly right. I mean, we've got to figure out the pull, the guys in field will solve for the push. We're going to get it in the back door, now what we going to do to get it out the front door. So I mean, we've got to get -- the equity is great, but I think we can improve it. And the you're exactly right. Rodger's team will get it in the back door. And in this track, Jim's team's going to figure out how to get it out the front door.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay. And then shifting to fountain. I believe that's weakened as the year has progressed. There was this promotion you were lapping. But can you give us an update on conditions in the fountain component of your business, and your outlook for founta
componenttext: Okay, okay. And then shifting to fountain. I believe that's weakened as the year has progressed. There was this promotion you were lapping. But can you give us an update on conditions in the fountain component of your business, and your outlook for fountain?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the fountain, we had -- we lapped the large onetime. We had a lot of activity that was going on out there that we have to go against. We're -- as we look at it, we're seeing the traffic in QSR is up about 1%. So we're watching that. We're sti
componenttext: Yes. I think the fountain, we had -- we lapped the large onetime. We had a lot of activity that was going on out there that we have to go against. We're -- as we look at it, we're seeing the traffic in QSR is up about 1%. So we're watching that. We're still very bullish on it. 42,000 new valves. The guys have a goal, the same this year, on especially getting more diet out there. So that we -- that helps us with the diet and with our sweet program on Diet Dr Pepper. We're still -- the fountain team has delivered great results. And sometimes, when you get these big hits, you've got to lap them. And so we didn't think it was bad of a hit for us.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of John Faucher with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of John Faucher with JPMorgan.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick follow-up on the question about 7UP. Is 7UP getting hit because of sort of this move to -- I mean, are you seeing a direct response with the sparkling waters replacing it, given maybe what was perceived as a healthier halo surrounding some of
componenttext: Just a quick follow-up on the question about 7UP. Is 7UP getting hit because of sort of this move to -- I mean, are you seeing a direct response with the sparkling waters replacing it, given maybe what was perceived as a healthier halo surrounding some of the lemon lime category? Or do you have any -- I guess, do you have any information on switching? And then finally, some thoughts on diets. You seen any stabilization of the trend here? And do you still think that Diet Pepper sort of operates a little bit on its own aura there where it can avoid some of the negatives that we're seeing more on the cola side?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, John. For years, we've always noticed that lemon lime seems to be the last spot where the CSD player switches over. And so we're looking at that saying, "Oh, how do we get -- we've got them in, now let's get more in there, keep them in there once we
componenttext: Yes, John. For years, we've always noticed that lemon lime seems to be the last spot where the CSD player switches over. And so we're looking at that saying, "Oh, how do we get -- we've got them in, now let's get more in there, keep them in there once we get them in." The sparkling waters are very big on, especially the flavored that are similar to it. So we've going to get a lot of findings from that as we do the lean track. The Kaizen, the guys doing the work in the street, I mean, we just think there's things out there that we haven't picked up on, that we've got to be very focused on and get this brand back where it's got a growth potential again. And on the diets. Yes, the diets. I mean, you heard me in my prepared remarks. We've got -- we're coming back with Lil' Sweet again, and we've got a great campaign there. We're seeing -- we're performing better than the category, but I think we're going to continue to see some headwinds there for diets. But our plan is stay focused on them, make people understand that they have a great taste, they want a great taste, and that they're safe. And so we'll continue to go down that line, and there'll be some headwinds, but we're very happy that we're outperforming the category there.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016

componenttext: Our final question comes from the line of Rob Ottenstein with Evercore ISI.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: On RCI, I'm getting the sense of that you may be shifting the mix a little bit to projects that are more top line focused than bottom line focused. Is that correct? And does that suggest that perhaps you've got more runway in terms of top line focused pro
componenttext: On RCI, I'm getting the sense of that you may be shifting the mix a little bit to projects that are more top line focused than bottom line focused. Is that correct? And does that suggest that perhaps you've got more runway in terms of top line focused projects at this point? And related to that, in terms of your pipeline of projects for 2016, how does that compare to prior years?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rob, clearly recently, we've probably done more growth-type projects. But really, that's just part of the evolution of lean. You always start -- lean is embedded in supply chain. It grew out of Toyota in supply chain. And so it makes sense to apply the to
componenttext: Rob, clearly recently, we've probably done more growth-type projects. But really, that's just part of the evolution of lean. You always start -- lean is embedded in supply chain. It grew out of Toyota in supply chain. And so it makes sense to apply the tools. And those of you that were around us back 5 years ago, you heard us talk about Warehouse Direct and supply chain and warehouses and lowering inventory levels, et cetera. So this is really just a natural evolution. We want balance, of course. We want to work on projects that contribute to growth and strength in our brands. And that's obvious. It's not -- we don't have a targeted mix with respect -- remember, we don't -- we actually -- we don't even use of the word productivity much around here, actually. We talk about waste elimination. We don't really focus -- your question goes to whether we -- how we're focusing on eliminating cost, really, on the productivity side. And all we do is worry about what are customers paying us to do? Where's the value add in the value stream? And get rid of everything else. And I think the tracks are also a balance of involvement of the organization. So we want our field people, our sales management people, we want them involved in improvement activities. It's just another improvement activity. This organization is about total engagement. Nobody sits on the sidelines, nobody watches, nobody's outside the process. And I think that also goes to making sure that our field teams are working on things that are important to them. And of course, what's important to them are sales activities.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016

componenttext: Of course, Peñafiel is principally -- is still principally Mexico. We're rolling it out with success in Hispanic markets in U.S. But its double-digit growth is principally Mexico. componenttext: Well, and how much was Peñafiel up in the U.S.? And where are you in terms of rolling it out?

componenttextpreview: I think the last quarter, it's very early in terms of rollout. This, Rob, goes to -- we had Peñafiel in the market previously, we sort of -- it was sort of U.S. made. That was probably not the best strategy in terms of authenticity for the brand for its
componenttext: I think the last quarter, it's very early in terms of rollout. This, Rob, goes to -- we had Peñafiel in the market previously, we sort of -- it was sort of U.S. made. That was probably not the best strategy in terms of authenticity for the brand for its consumers. So more recently, we're now bringing it up from Mexico. And you're seeing lots of other products in this space coming up. But it's still small. So that's a lot of opportunity. Let me go to Dr Pepper, if that's okay. I think you then want to know percent changes on Dr Pepper on a bottler -- as we measure, bottler case sales. So throughput cases. The brand is -- regular Dr Pepper, actually, I'll round it to down 1%, but it was actually even less than that fourth quarter. And on a bottler case, diet was down 4.5%. And if you look at Nielsen data, you'll see other diets down 6%, 7%, 8%.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Dr Pepper Snapple Group's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded and includes a slide presentation, which can be accessed at www.drpeppersnapple.com. The call and sl
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to Dr Pepper Snapple Group's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded and includes a slide presentation, which can be accessed at www.drpeppersnapple.com. The call and slides will also be available for replay and download after the call has ended. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to introduce Heather Catelotti, Vice President, Investor Relations. Heather, you may begin.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jackie, and good morning, everyone. Before we begin, I would like to direct your attention to the safe harbor statement and remind you that this conference call contains forward-looking statements, including statements concerning our future fin
componenttext:
Thank you, Jackie, and good morning, everyone. Before we begin, I would like to direct your attention to the safe harbor statement and remind you that this conference call contains forward-looking statements, including statements concerning our future financial and operational performance. These forward-looking statements should also be considered in connection with cautionary statements and disclaimers contained in the safe harbor statement in this morning's earnings press release and our SEC filings. Our actual performance could differ materially from these statements, and we undertake no duty to update these forward-looking statements.
During this call, we may reference certain non-GAAP financial measures that reflect the way we evaluate the business and which we believe provide useful information for investors. Reconciliations of those non-GAAP measures to GAAP can be found in our earnings press release and on the Investors page at www.drpeppersnapple.com.
This morning's prepared remarks will be made by Larry Young, President and CEO; and Marty Ellen, our CFO. Following our prepared remarks, we will open the call for your questions. With that, let me turn the call over to Larry.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Heather and good morning, everyone. We had a solid start to the year, and as always, I'm proud of our teams for delivering against our strategy and key priorities. Our brands are strong, and we're consistently focused on driving improved execution
componenttext:
Thanks, Heather and good morning, everyone. We had a solid start to the year, and as always, I'm proud of our teams for delivering against our strategy and key priorities. Our brands are strong, and we're consistently focused on driving improved execution in the marketplace. RCI continues to embed deeper into the organization and deliver growth and productivity across the business.
For the quarter, bottler case sales increased 2% on 4 points of positive mix and price. We were able to achieve growth across our portfolio in both CSDs and noncarbs, with both increasing by 2%. Brand Dr Pepper increased 4%, reflecting growth in our Fountain foodservice business. Over half of this growth was due to timing of sales to a large bottling customer that we had planned for in the second quarter. 
Our Core 4 brands increased 3% -- decreased 3% as growth in Canada Dry was more than offset by declines of 7UP, Sunkist Soda and A&W. Crush and Schweppes grew 6% and 10%, respectively on increased promotional activity at a larger retailer. Squirt grew by 3% and Peñafiel increased 5% in the quarter, while lapping 20% growth a year ago. All other CSDs decreased 1% in the quarter.
In noncarbs, Snapple increased 4% in the quarter, Hawaiian Punch decreased 7% as planned, driven by price increases on singleserve packages. And Mott's decreased 4%, again as planned, on lower promotional activity and continued declines in the juice category. Clamato grew 10% in the quarter, primarily on increased promotional activity. And our water category grew by 22%. Aguafiel grew double digits. And continued strong contribution to growth were also driven by a number of our allied brands, including Bai and FIJI. All other noncarb brands decreased 2% in the quarter.
Our allied brand strategy is enabling us to quickly capture growth in emerging categories. I am pleased to announce 2 new recent partnerships, Core Hydration, a purified water rich with and minerals; and , a cold brewed ready-to-drink coffee. We believe both products have strong market potential.
Building our brands is a key component of our strategy. And our calendar for the summer is packed with programs that will engage and connect with our consumers as well as drive excitement with every retail and bottling partners. First, I hope you all swa recently that Beverage Digest reported that Regular Dr Pepper is now the fourth largest CSD brand in the category, surpassing a large competitive flavor brand. It's a good reminder that we compete in flavored CSDs, not colas. And Nielsen data shows that flavors over the past 2 [ph] are up in retail dollars by almost 4%.  
That is an exciting win for the Dr Pepper brand, and our summer line up of activity will keep the momentum going. Our Pick Your Pepper program will offer millennial consumers 150 one-of-a-kind labels on 20-ounce singleserve bottles that will allow them to express their individuality. 
We know that our Li'l Sweet campaign was a huge success for Diet Dr Pepper last year. So we brought them back for an encore performance highlighting the great sweet taste of Diet Dr Pepper. 
We're also driving a big push behind Cherry Dr Pepper, with a new media campaign inclusive of both traditional and digital media and activation elements at retail. We know that this product is an entry point into the brand, specifically with Hispanic consumers, so we are leveraging to bring new consumers into the franchise. 
We're rolling out 7.5-ounce slim cans across our key CSD brands and our DSD network. As we know, this is a consumer-preferred package. We'll get Schweppes sparkling waters into more consumers' hands with incremental trial activity. And we'll top off the summer with incremental media and activity behind Cherry 7UP.
Mott's will feature characters from Universal's The Secret LIfe of Pets movie on several key products throughout the summer and will drive incremental points of interruption with a new patriotic Snapple LTL. We've also added 2 new flavors to our straight up tea lineup, Honey Green and Herbal . to spice of summer gatherings, Clamato with partner with an authentic Mexican beer as the original mixer. I'm sure you'll agree we've got a great lineup for the summer.
Now let me turn the call over to Marty to walk you through our financial results and our 2016 guidance.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Larry. Let me begin with a high-level financial summary of the quarter. Sales volume increased 1%, with reported net sales up 2%. Currency-neutral net sales were up 4%. Core operating income was up 13% and core operating margin was 20.6%, up
componenttext:
Thank you, Larry. 
Let me begin with a high-level financial summary of the quarter. Sales volume increased 1%, with reported net sales up 2%. Currency-neutral net sales were up 4%. Core operating income was up 13% and core operating margin was 20.6%, up 190 basis points. Core EPS was up 16% in the quarter. Excluding foreign currency translation, core operating income was up 14% and core EPS was up 17%. All in all, some good results for the quarter. 
Now let me provide some further detail.  Reported net sales increased 2% in the first quarter on 3 points of favorable product and package mix, 1 percentage point of price realization and a 1% increase in sales volumes. Reducing this net sales growth was just over a 1.5 points of unfavorable foreign currency translation and almost 1 point of unfavorable segment mix as a result of our higher proportion of this year of concentrate sales to finished goods case sales. Net sales was further reduced by just over 0.5 point for higher discounts driven by accrual timing in our Fountain foodservice business that will reverse in the third quarter of the year. 
Reported gross margins increased 100 basis points in the quarter, increasing from 58.5% last year to 59.5% this year, of which 30 basis points was driven by the favorable effect of unrealized mark-to-market commodity changes. Lower commodity costs, primarily PET and aluminum, increased gross margins by 100 basis points in the quarter. And continued productivity benefits, including those from RCI, increased gross margins by another 40 basis points. The impact of positive net pricing in the quarter also increased gross margins by 40 basis points. The effect of mix, mostly product, reduced gross margins by 70 basis points. And finally, foreign currency reduced gross margins in the quarter by 30 basis points as Mexico sources certain inputs in U.S. dollars, as finished products sold in Canada are sourced from the U.S.
For the quarter, SG&A, excluding depreciation, decreased by $6 million on a planned marketing reduction of $12 million, driven by timing of media and programming, favorable foreign currency translation and a reduction in transportation costs driven by lower fuel costs. These decreases were partially offset by inflationary and certain other increases in operating expenses. Furthermore, included in our core SG&A is a $4 million arbitration award associated with our Mexican joint venture. Specific to our segment, this charge reduced their reported operating income growth by 24 percentage points.  Depreciation and amortization declined $1 million in the quarter. 
Below the operating line, net interest expense increased $6 million in the quarter, primarily reflecting higher rates from our January debt refinance and an overall higher debt balance. Our reported effective tax rate was 35.2% compared to 35.7% last year.
Moving on to cash flow, cash from operating activities was $177 million, up $76 million compared to last year, primarily driven by timing of working capital and the increase in net income. Capital spending was $27 million compared to $20 million last year. Total distributions to our shareholders were $269 million, with $179 million in shares repurchased and $90 million in dividends paid.
Moving on to RCI, I'll give a brief update on the progress of a few of our lean tracks, but first, I would like to mention that last month, we were honored at the Lean and Six Sigma Conference with its first ever Deployment of the Year award, specifically recognizing the depth, breadth and scope of our RCI rollout across the company. This is tremendous recognition for us, though we always remind ourselves that RCI is a journey that never ends and we continue to have a long runway of opportunity.
From a growth standpoint, the Dr Pepper smaller packages growth lean track has closed over 1,100 distribution voids in a large retailer. And in the Plains region, our allied brand distribution and availability track netted almost a 9% increase in distribution of priority SKUs. And these are great examples of engaging our partners in the value chain and together using proven process improvement methods to drive even better levels of retail execution.
Our 7UP lean track is under way, and the team has done extensive analytic rigor on the brand and they have gone to in some of our larger markets. We've got multiple kaizens in key markets scheduled over the next couple of months where we will identify and attack the root causes of the brand's recent performance in those markets. And we're seeing early wins in our productivity track for reducing both DSD driver turnover and nonworking media spend. Again, just a very few examples of the improvement initiatives taking place across our business every single day.
Now moving to 2016 guidance. We expect reported net sales to be up approximately 2%, inclusive of a foreign currency translation headwind of about 1%, which is down from our prior guidance of a 2% headwind. 
We also now expect EPS to be in the high end of our previously communicated range of $4.20 to $4.30. This is inclusive of about a 2.5-point headwind from both foreign currency translation and transaction combined versus the 4% that we had originally expected. 
We continue to expect total company sales volume to be about flat. Given the category headwinds in CSDs, we expect CSDs to be about flat, while we expect noncarbs to be up slightly. Remember that our noncarb volume performance is being tempered this year by pricing actions taken across several of our Warehouse Direct brands and the possible termination of the Aguafiel 10-liter business in Mexico. We still expect continued growth from our noncarb brands such as Snapple, Clamato and our allied brand portfolio. 
On a total company basis, we expect combined price and mix to be over 2.5%. Our January 1 concentrate price increase will drive about 40 basis points of this increase, and price increases on our Warehouse Direct brands will drive an additional 20 basis points. The remainder will come from mix as a result of stronger growth from smaller CSD packages and brands such as Snapple, Clamato and our allied brand portfolio.
Moving on to cost of goods, given our hedge positions and current market prices for our unhedged positions, we now expect packaging and ingredients to be about 0.5% deflationary on a constant volume-mix basis. This expectation still reflects deflation in commodities such as PET and aluminum, but also now reflects less of a headwind on corn than we originally expected, driven primarily by more favorable pricing of corn coproducts from which we derive our net price for corn. For modeling purposes, remember that growth from some of our noncarb portfolio and allied brands will also increase the dollar value of cost of goods, and also remember that cost of goods is negatively impacted by foreign currency transaction, as I mentioned a moment ago. Collectively, all of the factors I mentioned above should result in roughly similar gross margins in 2016.
Moving to SG&A, we continue to expect an increase of approximately $20 million in health and welfare and other insurance costs compared to the more favorable trends we experienced in 2015. We also still expect general inflation in our field labor costs to increase operating expenses by approximately $20 million. And while we still expect favorability from lower fuel costs in 2016, we will experience rate increases from our third-party carriers. That said, we still believe we will be able to achieve productivity benefits from RCI that will help offset a portion of these increases. 
Based on some recent favorable marketing return on investment results and incremental opportunities across our ales, sparkling waters and juice brands, we're spending about $5 million more in marketing than we initially expected. And as I mentioned a few moments ago, we recorded an unplanned arbitration award of $4 million related to our Mexican joint venture and the possible termination of the Aguafiel 10-liter business. As I also mentioned earlier, this charge is included in core results.
Now moving below segment operating profit, our net interest expense will be around 4.5% on our $2.9 billion of debt, which implies an increase of approximately $14 million, driven primarily by our recent debt issuances and refinancing.  Our full year core tax rate is still expected to be approximately 35.5%, and we continue to expect capital spending to be approximately 3% of net sales.  We also continue to expect to repurchase approximately $650 million to $700 million of our common stock in 2016, subject to market conditions. 
Now let me highlight a couple of phasing items that will help you update your models.
First, given the strengthening of the U.S. dollar over the course of 2015, our foreign currency headwind will be more pronounced in the first half of the year. Second, as Larry mentioned earlier in his prepared remarks, over half of our growth in brand Dr Pepper in the first quarter was driven by timing of sales that were planned for in the second quarter. Third, we'll be potentially terminating a distribution agreement on our 10-liter Aguafiel business in Mexico, which we have planned for in the second quarter. Fourth, while we expect commodities to be about 0.5 point deflationary on a constant volume-mix basis for the full year, the deflation will be more pronounced in the first half of the year. Fifth, based on timing of prior year true-ups, the $20 million increase in health and welfare and other insurance costs will be heavily weighted in both the second and third quarters. And finally, while we expected a reduction in marketing investment in the first quarter, driven by media and programming shifts, we are expecting increased investment in both the second and third quarters. 
With that, let me turn the call back over to Larry.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marty. Before we open the lines for questions, let me leave you with a few brief, though consistent thoughts. Our core business remains strong and it's off to a good start. We're continuing to focus on unlocking growth in our priority brands thr
componenttext:
Thanks, Marty. Before we open the lines for questions, let me leave you with a few brief, though consistent thoughts. 
Our core business remains strong and it's off to a good start. We're continuing to focus on unlocking growth in our priority brands through integrated communication and execution, consumer-driven innovation, while also selectively adding to our allied brand portfolio to capture fast-moving consumer trends. We're continuing to embed RCI further into our culture. And we're seeing meaningful improvements in growth and productivity across the company, and it also serves as a meaningful contribution to the successful execution of our strategy. And importantly, we remain committed to returning excess free cash to our shareholders over time. 
Operator, we're ready for our first question.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Kevin Grundy with Jefferies.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Kevin Grundy with Jefferies.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: First one for Marty on the guidance, I just want to make sure I'm clear with the moving parts. So moved to the higher end of the $4.20 to $4.30. That seems like that it can be explained really by some weakness in the U.S. dollar. So Marty, is it just basi
componenttext: First one for Marty on the guidance, I just want to make sure I'm clear with the moving parts. So moved to the higher end of the $4.20 to $4.30. That seems like that it can be explained really by some weakness in the U.S. dollar. So Marty, is it just basically commodity's a bit better, offset by the arbitration and higher levels of investment?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Kevin. Just to ground everybody, I would say that the new news relative to guidance today would be commodities and foreign exchange, both positive and in the $0.10 range combined. The arbitration award, of course, is new news that's in our core resul
componenttext: Yes, Kevin. Just to ground everybody, I would say that the new news relative to guidance today would be commodities and foreign exchange, both positive and in the $0.10 range combined. The arbitration award, of course, is new news that's in our core results that's going to cost us. It's a little over $0.01. We are going to spend a little more in marketing. We would have done this anyway, based on some findings we had on those product categories, a couple of cents. So you can take away from this call there is some upside of $0.07 for the year. We're not changing our guidance. We like the performance in the first quarter. We like the execution. We like where our strategy is taking us. And so we're very pleased. And quite frankly, it's just early in the year to think about changes at this point.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And okay, that's helpful. one more if I may for Larry on topic of excise tax risk in the U.S. So Larry, the proposal in Philadelphia have gotten quite a bit of attention, and one of the leading presidential candidate says he's probably supporting it. So I
componenttext: And okay, that's helpful. one more if I may for Larry on topic of excise tax risk in the U.S. So Larry, the proposal in Philadelphia have gotten quite a bit of attention, and one of the leading presidential candidate says he's probably supporting it. So I know that Roger runs packaged beverages for you guys as current share in the ABA. I was hoping to get some updated thoughts on this topic. And specifically, should investors be any more concerned about the potential for excise tax risk here at the federal level in the U.S.?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't. These things go on and on. You said Roger's on the -- he's chair of the ABA board. And Jim Johnston also sits on the board executive committee. I think we've got great plan out there across for federal and our states and cities. It's a -- the
componenttext: No, I don't. These things go on and on. You said Roger's on the -- he's chair of the ABA board. And Jim Johnston also sits on the board executive committee. I think we've got great plan out there across for federal and our states and cities. It's a -- there's one coming up all the time. And the team has got a good handle on it, and it doesn't concern me that much.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, all we said on the call was about half of the 4% DCS growth came from this timing of this large [indiscernible]. So the brand was still up. BCS again, bottler case sales as we look at it, which is the reporting through all of our bottling partners i
componenttext: Well, all we said on the call was about half of the 4% DCS growth came from this timing of this large [indiscernible]. So the brand was still up. BCS again, bottler case sales as we look at it, which is the reporting through all of our bottling partners in terms of real throughput. Actually Regular was up 5.9%. again, that's going to be -- include the Fountain. And on a BCS basis, diet was only down 2.1%. I think it was down -- it's going to show down further in the Nielsen that you all see. But our bottler case sales basis is down 2, which is a step improvement.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, and then 2 quick ones for Larry. Larry, the first thing is, you've talked about this in the past, but are you surprised by how sustainable pricing environment has been in North America? And as you look next 12 to 18 months given your experience
componenttext: All right, and then 2 quick ones for Larry. Larry, the first thing is, you've talked about this in the past, but are you surprised by how sustainable pricing environment has been in North America? And as you look next 12 to 18 months given your experience on the bottling side, do you feel like the change in [indiscernible] will have any impact on this environment?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't. I'm very pleased with how the pricing is. I'm not surprised over it because I mean we've been able to go well and execute. We're doing much more, not just Dr Pepper Snapple, but the industry with different packages. I think we're looking at m
componenttext: No, I don't. I'm very pleased with how the pricing is. I'm not surprised over it because I mean we've been able to go well and execute. We're doing much more, not just Dr Pepper Snapple, but the industry with different packages. I think we're looking at more at what consumer's wanting. I think our retail partners have looked at it and decided that it's not always just the price off. There's a lot of other ways to deliver value to a customer. So I don't see any changes in the pricing environment.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then lastly for me, Larry, if you look at your noncarbonated portfolio, there are some bright spots, but then, you have [indiscernible] than we would like it to be. We've seen some of your competitors clean up their ingredients a little bit, and that
componenttext: And then lastly for me, Larry, if you look at your noncarbonated portfolio, there are some bright spots, but then, you have [indiscernible] than we would like it to be. We've seen some of your competitors clean up their ingredients a little bit, and that has helped. Have you considered cleaning up the ingredients in some of those portfolio to see if that gets...

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've been doing that through the years with our Mott's. We've been bringing the sugar down. We've probably taken Hawaiian Punch down several times. We've got the Hawaiian Punch for breakfast. So we got a lot of different things that we always work on out
componenttext: We've been doing that through the years with our Mott's. We've been bringing the sugar down. We've probably taken Hawaiian Punch down several times. We've got the Hawaiian Punch for breakfast. So we got a lot of different things that we always work on out there with it. And the biggest thing when you look at our volume, it was pricing that we planned on. I mean, we looked at it and we knew that we are going to have the volume down. But I think you can tell by our results, it's been a pretty good trade-off.

componenttext: Just kind of looking at the Fountain foodservice question from another angle. There's been a little bit of volatility obviously in there. How should we think about a run rate on this business, the growth rate going forward? And is there any other watch-outs as far as volatility as we work through 2016?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bill, it's Marty. As we've talked previously about Fountain, we've done a pretty good job in our Fountain penetration. I think you know where we are in terms of our national account presence in Fountain, which isn't always where you make your money in Fou
componenttext: Bill, it's Marty. As we've talked previously about Fountain, we've done a pretty good job in our Fountain penetration. I think you know where we are in terms of our national account presence in Fountain, which isn't always where you make your money in Fountain. Just like in bottling cans, it's if we make money up a notch, [ph] we make money in small local accounts. We've talked in the past, we've been running on that forecasting for this year. But I'm telling you our past history, as a result of that, has been sort of low single-digit's growth in Fountain case sales. And so we've done pretty well actually.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just one quick housekeeping follow-up. I know you mentioned the possible change in Aguafiel. I think in the past, you called this a 0.5 point impact on your consolidated volumes for the full year, and I think just repeated starting i
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just one quick housekeeping follow-up. I know you mentioned the possible change in Aguafiel. I think in the past, you called this a 0.5 point impact on your consolidated volumes for the full year, and I think just repeated starting in the second quarter. Is that still a good number to think about?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bill, it is, but I want to clarify what I said in my prepared remarks. We have not terminated distribution yet because it is sort of related to and tied up in the ultimate resolution of what happens to our joint venture in Mexico, which produces this 10-l
componenttext: Bill, it is, but I want to clarify what I said in my prepared remarks. We have not terminated distribution yet because it is sort of related to and tied up in the ultimate resolution of what happens to our joint venture in Mexico, which produces this 10-liter product. It's not a very profitable product at all, but we can't stop distributing until we settle some other issues with the other party.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Judy Hong with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So first, just in terms of your decision to spend a little bit more on marketing, and I think you've talked about Fountain a little bit here, some of the discounting actions in that channel. Can you just broadly talk to us about sort of decision? It seems
componenttext: So first, just in terms of your decision to spend a little bit more on marketing, and I think you've talked about Fountain a little bit here, some of the discounting actions in that channel. Can you just broadly talk to us about sort of decision? It seems like maybe a little bit more focused on volume and really trying to take opportunity of some of the growth of these out there. So is this a little bit of a change in strategy or more kind of tactical move on your part? And then the other question, just on concentrate segment and the price mix impact from the Fountain volatility, can you just clarify that as well?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, Judy, yes, it's Marty. Let me just get rid of the -- the concentrate question, as we said in our annual January 1 concentrate increase on concentrate and syrup prices go up as well, we said is about 40 basis points in pricing spread over all of our
componenttext: Okay, Judy, yes, it's Marty. Let me just get rid of the -- the concentrate question, as we said in our annual January 1 concentrate increase on concentrate and syrup prices go up as well, we said is about 40 basis points in pricing spread over all of our $6 billion-plus in sales. So there's nothing new there. I mean, the timing issue in the first quarter with shipment had no impact on pricing per se. It's simply the quantity of syrup. And the accrual is the timing, as I said in my prepared remarks, we accrued a little more in the first quarter. It's going to come back in the third quarter. Let me shift over to marketing and again, it was really about specific opportunities in ale, sparkling waters and juices. There's going to be some specific emphasis on Mott's. So let me just pullback and sort of deal with this timing issue in the first quarter as well. we'll get that off the table. One of the things we talked last year ago and continue to talk about some of the updated strategy work we've been doing for our key brands. And I would tell you through that process, which took us all of last year, we came up with some different conclusions about communications and messaging for many -- for some of our brands that I would tell you were different from some of our prior points of view. So we took the input from initially what was 35,000 consumer surveys that I think got culled down to roughly 25,000 good surveys about how they felt about our brands on a number of dimensions. And as a result, we're changing our communication messaging. And quite frankly because we've decided to make some changes, it's taking a little more time than we originally -- not more time than we thought because we planned for this. But the lighter spend in the first quarter was really a function of that new time line for us to create a new creative. And so we planned for that. We're going to still spend 7.5% of sales this year, like we always have. as I said in the incremental $5 million, these opportunities came up. Schweppes, that category is growing double digits, some insights on Mott's. And so I would call that sort of evolution, not -- nothing -- evolution of our return on investment insights and process to tell us where best to spend some money. In this case, we didn't just shift, we added $5 million.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay. And then just final clarification question. So the increased investments you've use taken in body armor, it sounds like maybe you're getting more territory from a distribution standpoint. So maybe is there a way to quantify how much this is
componenttext: Got it. Okay. And then just final clarification question. So the increased investments you've use taken in body armor, it sounds like maybe you're getting more territory from a distribution standpoint. So maybe is there a way to quantify how much this is adding to allied brands growth? And are there other allied brands that this year, you're getting more distribution that could be more meaningful in terms of the growth outlook?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, well, in terms of the additional investment in body armor, there's no more addition. We had an opportunity to acquire some more equity. We've looked at how the brand is performing, and it's performing quite well. And we thought it was in opportunity
componenttext: Okay, well, in terms of the additional investment in body armor, there's no more addition. We had an opportunity to acquire some more equity. We've looked at how the brand is performing, and it's performing quite well. And we thought it was in opportunity to again, expand our position, even though we're still on a relative basis small shareholder. But we just thought it would -- of these small investment solidify our partnership with these entrepreneurs and it's important. And so we decide to do it. Judy, in terms of -- since you asked, in terms of expanded opportunities, as Larry said, we -- the pipeline is full of opportunities, as I said last time. We will be entering a new category for us on the distribution side, ready-to-drink coffee. It's a $2 billion category. just that category, you'll see the brand. We're going to -- that's going to phase in. They have some existing distributors. Some, we can take oer be immediately; some, over time. But we begun the process. And of course, core hydration is getting traction. A lot of happening, of course, in that category. It's a somewhat crowded category, but some would say you can't have too few waters given the growth in that category. And it should remind everybody here that this strategy enables us to move with the consumer quickly, quicker than we believe we could do on our own, and we think we're taking advantage of that.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Just a couple of questions, but really, both around trying to disaggregate the drivers of your top line growth to get a better sense of sustainability, which is all we're thinking about. I remember the past couple of quarters, it's been kind of half or more of growth coming from allied brands. Because what I'm trying to get to is what your top line growth would have been this quarter kind of. I don't know how to call it,, core bottling can or true bottling can excluding food and service, excluding allied brands. give us a sense of that?

componenttext: Well I'll -if you look at volume on the allied brands, you're probably just under half, okay, in the 40% range in terms of contributing volume growth. that of course, in dollars, they're going to be higher. Because on a rate per case basis, they're higher than our core brand, with lots of good profitability.

componenttextpreview: No. it's just the portfolio for allied brands. And the shift in -- let me -- before I go on to Fountain, that shouldn't be a surprise, right? The whole reason we embarked on this strategy is to capture growth. So given the fact that we are still sort of 8
componenttext: No. it's just the portfolio for allied brands. And the shift in -- let me -- before I go on to Fountain, that shouldn't be a surprise, right? The whole reason we embarked on this strategy is to capture growth. So given the fact that we are still sort of 80% CSDs, and everybody knows what's happening in that category even though we've outperformed it, should be no surprise that in that noncarb portfolio, the allied brands are contributing. And when we grow Clamato and Snapple alongside, which are 2 of our highest profitable case products, it should be also no surprise why we're getting the margin performance that we're getting. the, Ali, the Fountain order timing was probably worth $4 million or something in terms of revenue.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay. And I mean, you understand the background of the question, you guys know. And you kind of talked about this, at least offline, is a lot of investors asking, well, is more than half of the growth top line-wise of allied brands, how much should
componenttext: Okay, okay. And I mean, you understand the background of the question, you guys know. And you kind of talked about this, at least offline, is a lot of investors asking, well, is more than half of the growth top line-wise of allied brands, how much should I pay for it distribution model, or a distributor as opposed to a brand owner? I think that's the underlying question. do you have any views on that obviously to allay people's fears, or just what this is something we should be doing right? We should be pivoting with a consumer a lot more. Is that the question we get, right, is how much to pay for the distributor.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ali, you guys can answer that question. The pipeline is full. We announced 2 more this morning. There's probably more than 2 dozen opportunity. So when I pull back, my answer your question is, you said pivot with the consumer. We're not fighting the consu
componenttext: Ali, you guys can answer that question. The pipeline is full. We announced 2 more this morning. There's probably more than 2 dozen opportunity. So when I pull back, my answer your question is, you said pivot with the consumer. We're not fighting the consumer. We're not trying to push back on the consumer. And through our money and resources as an effort to do that. We're not going to try to make brands that, consumers have said, serve a certain purpose for them and under the names of those brands and try to change them and change the perception of them in the marketplace. So of course, this is about innovating with a very, very fast-changing consumer. And while we're getting growth at some of these categories to the, it's really good. We'll see where the growth curves go. Some may fade over time just because consumers changed over time and they're changing quickly. So we play this without capital at risk. And we get to capture the growth quickly. And we've got a lot of people lined up to talk to us because they see that we can create for them alongside us and both win. And we think it's a very good strategy. You can put your own numbers on it, but what we see is a great opportunity to leverage something that is not so easily replicatable, which is 170 warehouses, 8,000 trucks and a massively powerful distribution system.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on that main exhibition is 170 warehouses, 8,000 trucks. One of the stories for your core brands has been distribution gains, right? So your frontier is in the U.S. or in Canada. It's not going to rural India, right? So there's distribution potential g
componenttext: So on that main exhibition is 170 warehouses, 8,000 trucks. One of the stories for your core brands has been distribution gains, right? So your frontier is in the U.S. or in Canada. It's not going to rural India, right? So there's distribution potential gain. Can you give us an update on that? So just from an ACV perspective, excluding kind of the newer allied brands, but just from an ACV perspective, where you are today on average for the core brand as I call it, not Core 4, but just your core brands, and where you were, say, 5 years ago or 3 years ago? Just some metric to to see the distribution gain has happened for your legacy brands.

componenttext: Ali, you're talking in the U.S., correct?

componenttext: Yes, yes, sorry. I mean in the U.S. I mean your opportunity for distribution gains in the U.S., yes.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a great question, too. So you look at a Core 4, we may have been in the mid-60s. We're well into the 70% or north range in distribution. Some of my -- I want to go back and remind everybody that there was still a lot of opportunity that we are c
componenttext: Yes, it's a great question, too. So you look at a Core 4, we may have been in the mid-60s. We're well into the 70% or north range in distribution. Some of my -- I want to go back and remind everybody that there was still a lot of opportunity that we are capturing at the core. We recognize that 7UP, 7UP challenged's for that, we're going to fix it. And what it was last year, closing Snapple voids, and we talked about the growth in closing Snapple voids. just some of the RCI growth tracks that we've done, which allows us to improve what some would say is the blocking and tackling of the business, but do it better than anybody shows that we can continue to grow our core brands. One of it was Canada Dry, again, closing voids we have a lean track on Canada Dry. So there's also -- there's a piece here that we think is very positive for us in terms of our improving execution capabilities of that are helping our core brands. I think everybody sometimes takes for granted that everybody's execution is at the same level. We may not be the best. We're not declaring we're the best, but we are pleased with the improvements we're making, and that does help that grow our core.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I have a question for Marty. In the past, you talked about the opportunity in Mexico to significantly expand distribution beyond the concentrated pockets you're currently in. So could you discuss a little bit about the progress of that init
componenttext: Okay. And then I have a question for Marty. In the past, you talked about the opportunity in Mexico to significantly expand distribution beyond the concentrated pockets you're currently in. So could you discuss a little bit about the progress of that initiative? And are there opportunities beyond the Peñafiel brand?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. so Bonnie, yes, we do have sort of distribution white space. We have closed some of it. As you probably know, we do use a lot of third-party distributors in what we otherwise do call DSD model. So there's still opportunity there. We're trying to stay
componenttext: Yes. so Bonnie, yes, we do have sort of distribution white space. We have closed some of it. As you probably know, we do use a lot of third-party distributors in what we otherwise do call DSD model. So there's still opportunity there. We're trying to stay focused where we have strength and where our brands and then really well. A number of years ago, probably 4, 5 years ago, we were probably more aggressively expanding and probably spending more money than we should have. I wouldn't say the strategy wasn't working so well. So we've reined a little bit, so a little bit more targeted now. It's a little more strategic now. We're not in a rush. We want to capture market opportunities well, not hurriedly. As you know, the business there is doing real well. The Peñafiel business has continued to do well some say, why did the brand only grow 5%? Why didn't it [ph] grow 20% last year? At 5%, when we looked around, it's still pretty good relative to the market down there. As you know, we're building a new water plant. We announced that I think in the start of the year at the last year, because we are is simply out of capacity, and that's outside Mexico City. So all in all, our teens and Mexico is doing really well but this is perform extraordinary well. as I said this morning, absent the JV settlement charge, they're at 6% top line, would have driven 24% operating profit growth. We like that model a lot.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll respond and Larry may add something. So yes, the RCI track is just getting going. We think we've got really good team of people on this. And there are some very early, early observations, but too early to share. You make a good point. We have s
componenttext: Well, I'll respond and Larry may add something. So yes, the RCI track is just getting going. We think we've got really good team of people on this. And there are some very early, early observations, but too early to share. You make a good point. We have spent a considerable amount of that brand. And we're here to tell you that the messaging and communication and target for some past advertising we now know is -- was not on point with the 7UP consumer. And as I said, I think to Judy's comment earlier when I alluded to sort of now having to change the messaging, which is impacting, impacted at least the timing of spend into the early part of this year, there's a brand that's a big part of it.

componenttextpreview: I wanted to just talk a little bit about the packaged beverages margins, and sort of understanding maybe some of the mix pieces and spending movement that's going through there. Because if you look at the margin for Packaged Beverages, historically, Q1's
componenttext: I wanted to just talk a little bit about the packaged beverages margins, and sort of understanding maybe some of the mix pieces and spending movement that's going through there. Because if you look at the margin for Packaged Beverages, historically, Q1's been a dramatically lower margin -- not dramatically, but let's say 150 to 200 basis points lower than the full year margin. If we look at this this year, you've obviously got a big bump up there. If we see even remotely close similar sequential improvement in the margin over the balance of the year as we've seen in past years, that would imply just tremendous margin upside here. So can you talk a little bit about specifically the drivers there, maybe some mix impacts, raw materials, and how we should see that going through the year?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Marty. So let me help you guide you guys here. So when you look at the absolute level of first quarter margins for Packaged Beverages, I think the one call that I would give you that's worth about, and you're talking of course about operating margins
componenttext: It's Marty. So let me help you guide you guys here. So when you look at the absolute level of first quarter margins for Packaged Beverages, I think the one call that I would give you that's worth about, and you're talking of course about operating margins, probably the -- they're a piece of the $12 million marketing benefit. Because we know that's timing, probably helped our operating margins by about 50 basis points, okay? So there -- so given their current mix, given current levels of input costs, even given current levels of foreign exchange because we have our WD Canada business as part of the segment. So taking current levels in the first quarter, we sort of get the margins you get, less I would say 50 basis points for the marketing shift. What we like about Packaged Beverages, and the reason that margins have ticked up the way they have, is that they're getting this extraordinary benefit from first and foremost, mix. And as I said earlier, they're benefiting from the allied brands. This is good business for us and it's good business for our brand owners. And in our WD portfolio, the products that are growing are some of our best margin products. As you know -- and oh, by the way, I would say we will take growth in all of those brands and traded them all day long for whether it's decline in Hawaiian Punch or for that matter, decline in 7UP. So enormous beneficial mix, and that of course, I sai d they've got a point in pricing. that pricing environment seems to be pretty good. Year-over-year, commodities and fuel are pretty important to them, okay, and drove probably $18 million or so of year-over-year improvement. But nevertheless, those are the prices of commodities today. That is the price of fuel today. oil is going up a little bit. And saw there 4 the current margin structure I'd say it looks to be where it is in Q1, absent what I'd call out as timing.

componenttext: Can we talk strategically about the allied brands for like a couple of questions? When you make an equity investment, do you get a board seat? headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, Bill. Look, so first of all, the small equity positions we take here carry no real governance rights, whether they be board seats, managerial strategy, what have you. That's why we spend a lot of time with these management teams, understanding
componenttext: All right, Bill. Look, so first of all, the small equity positions we take here carry no real governance rights, whether they be board seats, managerial strategy, what have you. That's why we spend a lot of time with these management teams, understanding their strategy, the opportunities that they see. Does it square up with the opportunity we see? Are they credible? What have they done in the past? There's a whole checklist we go through. And at some level, we want them to be able to fund the costs that they need to find as the brand on their and not, from us for what reason that we had to fund these businesses early days, we would therefore have to buy them or acquire a majority position which would cause the spirit of the company to go away. The ownership would leave pivotable just become a nascent brand inside Dr Pepper that we would have to, in essence, grow from a very, very low base. That's why we're not doing this because we don't -- there's no proven model. You may have won, but across this space with our key competitors a demonstrates anybody's ability to really create a breakthrough brand, however, you want to define that, a breakthrough brand do Novo the whole strategy is about capturing the passion and spirit of these people and bring something to the party that they absolutely need and we need. like I said, the pipeline is full of opportunities. I don't know how we could ever have had an innovation pipeline like we're seeing through the wood we have ever invented and coconut water, for example, and had a success of in the Vita Coco. Have we ever created a Bai and had a success of a Bai? If I -- Larry and I come to you and said, and in the examples of body armor, we are now going to compete in sports drinks. You know that category and you know it's a highly competitive category. Anybody that would have said you're crazy, and they would have had the right to say that. But here, we come with a brand that we don't capital at risk in any meaningful way. And yet we have a chance, but that management team, which is a very credible management team, [indiscernible] a point of difference. We think got a great strategy. They've got a great approach from the product to the pricing to the positioning, to how they're going to approach the channels. This is the opportunity. And some may go over time. But I'm telling you, we're just sort of full. We almost get to the point we decide how many things we can handle. And using RCI, we're deploying a lot of RCI to this to help us create certain onboarding process or as a mention, one here distribution and availability to help us even execute on these better.

componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to Dr Pepper Snapple Group's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call.
