The following slides will also be available for replay and download after the call has ended. [Operator Instructions] It's now my pleasure to introduce Heather Catelotti, Vice President, Investor Relations. Heather, you may begin.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Maria, and good morning, everyone. Before we begin, I would like to direct your attention to the state harbor statement and remind you that this conference call contains forward-looking statements, including statements concerning our financial
componenttext:
Thank you, Maria, and good morning, everyone. Before we begin, I would like to direct your attention to the state harbor statement and remind you that this conference call contains forward-looking statements, including statements concerning our financial and operational performance. These forward-looking statements should also be considered in connection with cautionary statements and disclaimers contained in the safe harbor statement in this morning's earnings press release and our SEC filings. Our actual performance could differ materially from these statements, and we undertake no duty to update these forward-looking statements.
During this call, we may reference certain non-GAAP financial measures that reflect the way we evaluate the business in which we believe provides useful information for investors. Reconciliations of these non-GAAP measures to GAAP can be found in our earnings press release and on the investors page at www.drpeppersnapple.com.
This morning's prepared remarks will be made by Larry Young, President and CEO; and Marty Ellen, our CFO. Following our prepared remarks, we will open the call for your questions.
With that, let me turn the call over to Larry.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Heather, and good morning, everyone. Once again, we posted another solid quarter as our teams continue to relentlessly focus against our strategy. We're on track with driving integrated communications and execution across our priority brands and R
componenttext:
Thanks, Heather, and good morning, everyone. Once again, we posted another solid quarter as our teams continue to relentlessly focus against our strategy. We're on track with driving integrated communications and execution across our priority brands and RCI continues to permeate throughout the organization and drive sustainable financial benefits.
For the quarter, bottler case sales increased 1% on almost 4 points of positive mix and price. Volumes grew across our portfolio with CSDs increasing by 1% and noncarbs increasing by 2%. Brand Dr Pepper decreased 1% in the quarter as continued strong growth in our fountain foodservice business was more than offset by declines in diet. Our Diet Dr Pepper business continues to significantly outperform the diet category, declining at about half the rate of all diets, driven by the strength of our Lil' Sweet campaign.
Our Core 4 brands also declined 1% as over 5% growth in Canada Dry was more than offset by declines in 7UP, A&W and Sunkist Soda. Crush and Schweppes grew 4% and 9% respectively, on increased activation at a large retailer. Squirt grew 8% on strong growth in both Mexico and the U.S. and Peñafiel grew 4%. All of the CSD brands decreased 2% in the quarter.
In noncarbs, Snapple declined 2% as growth from product innovation was more than offset by the effect a year ago of liquidating certain Snapple inventories. As a reminder, Snapple growth in the second quarter last year was 11%. Hawaiian Punch decreased 5%, as expected, driven primarily by price increases on single-serve packages. Mott's was flat in the quarter as growth in sauce was fully offset by decreases in juice driven by price increases on single-serve packages. Clamato grew 14% in the quarter, reflecting continued strong growth across Mexico, the U.S. and Canada.
Our water category grew 25% on growth in our allied brand portfolio, particularly Bai and FIJI and continued growth in Aguafiel. All of the noncarb brands decreased 10% in the quarter, almost entirely due to our exit of a Country Time distance.
Building our brands continue to be a critical element of our overall strategy and success and we've got another strong calendar programming that is targeted against our consumer insights for the back half of the year. Our regular Dr Pepper 20 ounce program highlights 150 unique labels that allow consumers to choose their favorite bottle that represents their individuality. While it's early on, we're seeing recent upward trends in our convenient and gas business and our consumers are showcasing their love for the bottles, on social platforms such as Instagram and Twitter. You can also even purchase your preferred bottle on eBay.
As I mentioned earlier, our diet Lil' Sweet campaign continues to drive impressive results for the brand and we'll start college football off strong with heavy media across TV and digital platforms and activation in large national accounts. And new this year, Larry Culpepper, will be tailgating across the country to bring Dr Pepper to every football gathering and is on Dr Pepper van. Our Dr Pepper Cherry push would bring new users into the franchise and consumers are enjoying A&W root beer floats at their summer parties. Core 4 is bringing back Monster famed many cans for Halloween, with an app that will bring the Monsters to life on their smart device.
Canada Dry will continue to capitalize on growth in the ale category with increased media throughout the rest of the year and will activate against Schweppes sparkling waters, honing in on the growing mature age. Snapple will remind consumers to make time for Snapple, with corky new real facts ads and we'll once again bring news to the TL with red, blue election themed LTOs.
Clamato has partnered with authentic Mexican beer to spice up outdoor gatherings as the original enchilada. You may have seen our Mott's secret life of pest page in a market and just in time for back-to-school, Mott's will support schools with bonus box hub for education.
As you've seen, we've got a tremendous amount of activity lined up that engages our consumers and gives our customers and partners programs to rally behind.
Now let me turn the call over to Marty to walk you through our financial results and our 2016 guidance.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Larry. Let me start with a high level financial summary of the quarter, which as Larry just said, reflected solid performance.Sales volume increased 1%. We reported net sales up 2%. Core operating income was up 6% and core operating margin was 2
componenttext:
Thanks, Larry. Let me start with a high level financial summary of the quarter, which as Larry just said, reflected solid performance.
Sales volume increased 1%. We reported net sales up 2%. Core operating income was up 6% and core operating margin was 22.8%, up 70 basis points. Core EPS was up 11% in the quarter. On a currency-neutral basis, net sales were up 4%. Core operating income was up 8% and core EPS was up 12%.
Now let me provide some further details. Reported net sales increased 2% on about 2.5 points of favorable product and package mix, just over 1 percentage point of price realization and a 1% increase in sales volumes. Reducing this net sales growth was just over 1.5% of foreign currency translation and almost 1 point of unfavorable segment mix, as concentrate sales were relatively higher this year.
Reported gross margins increased 120 basis points in the quarter, increasing from 59.3% last year to 60.5% this year, of which 90 basis points was driven by the favorable effect of unrealized mark-to-market commodity changes. Lower commodity costs, primarily PET and aluminum, increased gross margins by 60 basis points, and continued productivity benefits, including those from RCI as well as certain other packaging and ingredient cost reductions, increased gross margins by another 50 basis points. The impact of positive net pricing also increased gross margins by 50 basis points.
The effect of mix, mostly from products purchased from others, reduced gross margins by 100 basis points. And finally, foreign currency reduced gross margins in the quarter by 30 basis points as Mexico sources certain inputs in U.S. dollars and finished products sold in Canada are sourced from the U.S.
For the quarter, SG&A, excluding depreciation, increased by $4 million on inflationary and certain other increases and operating expenses, including a onetime $4 million cost associated with the transition of a certain employee benefit program. These increases were partially offset by favorable foreign currency translation, a reduction in transportation costs, driven by lower fuel prices, and $7 million of lower marketing investments year-over-year due to timing shifts of brand campaigns. Depreciation and amortization declined $2 million in the quarter.
Below the operating line, net interest expense increased $5 million, primarily reflecting overall higher debt balance and higher rates from our fourth quarter 2015 refinancing. Other income increased by $23 million in the quarter as a result of a $21 million gain on the extinguishment of a multiemployer pension plan withdraw liability. This gain has been excluded from our core results. Our reported effective tax rate was 35.3% compared to 35.5% last year.
Moving on to cash flow. Cash from operating activities was $407 million, net of the $35 million payment of the multiemployer pension plan liability. Cash from operating activities was up $58 million compared to last year, primarily driven by timing of certain working capital amount and the increase in net income adjusted for noncash items. Capital spending was $68 million compared to $42 million last year as we expect incrementally to further support our growth in Mexico. Our new mineral water plant north of Mexico City should be operational in the fourth quarter of this year.
For the first 6 months, total distributions to our shareholders were $493 million with 303 million in shares repurchased and $190 million in dividends paid.
Before I move on to guidance, let me give a quick update on Rapid Continuous Improvement. Our 2016 lean tracks are in full swing. We've already had over 75 Kaizen events across the organization, and we're seeing wins across the board. Our share a few now. In our Orlando DSD site, driver turnover has been reduced by 44%, driven by improved recruiting, on-boarding and performance management processes. Through this lean track nationally, we're also learning from our drivers other elements of waste that will enable us to further improve the effectiveness of our route delivery system. A job growth safety playbook, developed by our frontline employees, is driving a 25% recordable injury reduction year-over-year in the second quarter, helping drive 12 months trend rates down almost double digits. We've closed over 2,000 boards on Dr Pepper's smaller CSD packages in a large retailer through a similar process we use to close voids on other brands, and certain allied brands, are experiencing both double and triple digit growth rates, partial as a result of our track specifically focused on allied brand distribution and availability. And as I've mentioned before, we have a tremendous amount of our CI activity going on throughout the business in addition to our lean tracks. Branch managers and essential business unit gain 10 hours per week of additional customer-facing time by adapting the RCI principles at standard work. And our Mexican team has improved Peñafiel distribution with our third-party distributors by creating standard work for trade management and point-of-sale.
We have great urgency to improve the performance of brands 7UP. Our lean track is underway. And while there is still a great deal of work to do, the team has diligently focused on the components of brand messaging and execution in local markets. Supporting this is a deep inspection of pricing, packaging, channel and geographic competitive trends alongside those of 7UP. This insight should enable us to begin implementing certain changes in the balance of 2016. There's definitely more to come on 7UP. Again, this are just a very few examples of the vast improvement initiatives taking place across our insider business everyday.
Now let me move on to 2016 guidance. We continue to expect reported net sales to be up approximately 2%, inclusive of a foreign currency translation headwind of about 1%. Given our first half performance, we are increasing our full year core EPS guidance. We now expect core EPS to be in the $4.27 to $4.35 range. This is inclusive of what we now expect to be about a 3% headwind from both foreign currency translation and transaction combined versus the 2.5% that we had expected previously. We continue to expect total company sales volume to be about flat. Similar to our previous guidance, we expect CSDs is to be about flat while we expect noncarbs to be up slightly. Remember, that our noncarb volume performance is being tempered this year by pricing actions taken across several of our Warehouse Direct brands. However, we still expect continued growth from other noncarb brands such as Snapple, Clamato and our allied brand portfolio.
On a total company basis, we expect combined price and mix to be up about 3%. Our January 1 concentrate price increase will drive about 40 basis points of this increase and price increases on our Warehouse Direct brands will drive an additional 20 basis points. The remainder will come from mix as a result of stronger growth from smaller CSD packages and brands such as Snapple, Clamato and our allied brand portfolio.
Moving on to cost of goods. Given our hedge positions and current market prices for our unhedged positions, we now expect packaging and ingredients to be about 1% deflationary on a constant volume/mix basis. This expectation still reflects deflation and commodities such as PET and aluminum and as we have previously said, a headwind on corn driven primarily by increases in toll and fees and unfavorable pricing of corn core products, from which we derive our net core price. For modeling purposes, remember that growth from some of our noncarb portfolio and allied brands will also increase the dollar value of cost of goods. And also remember that cost of goods is negatively impacted by foreign currency transaction, as I mentioned a moment ago. Collectively, all the factors I mentioned above should result in roughly similar gross margins in 2016.
Moving to SG&A. We now expect an increase of approximately $15 million in health and welfare and other insurance costs versus the original $20 million that we had previously expected. We also still expect general inflation in our field labor costs to increase operating expenses by approximately $20 million. That said, we believe we will be able to achieve productivity benefits from RCI that will help offset a portion of these increases, and we're also now expecting favorability from lower fuel costs of about $10 million, more than half of which we have already experienced. We continue to expect marketing to be about 7.5% of sales for the year. This implies a significant uptick in the back half of the year, mostly in the third quarter.
Now moving below segment operating profit. Our net interest expense will be around 4.5% on our $2.9 billion of debt, which implies an increase of approximately $15 million, driven primarily by our fourth quarter 2015 debt refinancing. Our full year core tax rate is still expected to be approximately 35.5%, and we continue to expect capital spending to be approximately 3% of net sales, even with the spending for our new plant in Mexico.
We also continue to expect to repurchase approximately $650 million to $700 million of our common stock in 2016, subject to market conditions.
Now let me highlight a couple of additional aging items that will help you update your models. First, as previously mentioned, while we expect commodities to be deflationary for the full year, the deflation has already been experienced and our trends are expected to turn flat to slightly up for the balance of the year due to the year-over-year timing of a certain commodity-related rebate. And second, based on timing of prior year true-ups, both the third quarter and fourth quarter will experience an increase in health and welfare and other insurance costs.
With that said, let me turn the call back over to Larry.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marty. Before we open the lines for questions, let me leave you with a few brief but consistent thoughts. Once again, we posted solid results in the quarter. We're continuing to focus on driving integrated communication, innovation and execution a
componenttext:
Thanks, Marty. Before we open the lines for questions, let me leave you with a few brief but consistent thoughts. Once again, we posted solid results in the quarter. We're continuing to focus on driving integrated communication, innovation and execution across our key priority brands, while selectively adding to our allied brand portfolio to capture fast moving consumer trends.
We're continuing to embed RCI further into our culture, and we're seeing meaningful improvements in growth and productivity across the company. And importantly, we remain committed to returning excess free cash to our shareholders over time.
Operator, we're ready for our first question.

There are competitors in there, and it's very geographic. We're only going to be effective dealing with retailers other private label, for example, in the geographies where our plants are and assuming those plans have the capacity to do their volumes. Otherwise, transportation mix at sort of a nonstarter. And we're still going to aggressively pursue volumes in our plants where it makes sense to do so. At the same time, we will still do some cold-stacking around the energy category, and that business continues.

componenttext: Sure, the percentage that we own is small, but we also have contracts in it, but we have buy out and certain things like that. componenttext: Hey, Steve, it's Marty. Going with 7UP. We're doing a lot of work, as I've said. We're finding some insights. My comment earlier about the phasing of marketing 7UP as part of that because through our strategy working in our consumer insight, we're changing the messaging on the brand and that's going to roll out in the second half. There are some new and different thoughts that have we're going to try here in the second half of the year. It's a lot of work in progress. We're encouraged by it. Obviously, it is the weak spot in the Core 4 everything is actually performing fairly well. So more to come on that. It's a first half like the question was.

componenttextpreview: Yes, okay. Just stepping back, in May, we have the FDA announced new package in food and beverage label requirements, more focused on both the calorie disclosure as well as importantly, the added sugar disclosures. Just given your portfolio of skewing tow
componenttext: Yes, okay. Just stepping back, in May, we have the FDA announced new package in food and beverage label requirements, more focused on both the calorie disclosure as well as importantly, the added sugar disclosures. Just given your portfolio of skewing towards full calorie CSDs and full sugar beverages generally, I'm just curious how you're approaching that change? And do you have any clarity on the time line to implement? And then, any guesses on the impacts to your business? Any mitigation efforts in rebuilding, whether it be more accelerated portfolio shifts or more accelerated investments in small pack sizes and that kind of things? How are you thinking about the pending changes?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, on the changes, I mean we will follow the guidelines. And as far as of the sweep and beverages, we've been seeing growth come back into the sugared beverages. I don't see us changing anything there. I think we're glad to see there's going to be more
componenttext: Well, on the changes, I mean we will follow the guidelines. And as far as of the sweep and beverages, we've been seeing growth come back into the sugared beverages. I don't see us changing anything there. I think we're glad to see there's going to be more of a federal labeling instead of having 20 different than what's out there with really drives the cost up of the bottle -- of packaging and then distribution. So we were happy with that. We think the FDA be in our guys did a great job there on helping the through. But I don't see any significant impacts that I'll be too concerned about them.

componenttext: Yes, well we're not losing any shelf space and as I think what would helps us of there, Judy, is when we look at the number one ginger ale, number when we are, ginger ale #1, #2, we don't even have it on the shelves up here. I mean there's been one that wants to get into the coffee, they want to get into dairy, they want to get into the juice aisle, they want to get into the CSD aisle but most of them are retailers, most of our customers want them in a block. They keep them in the same area. And so we'll have to watch it. We're not that concerned with that. we think we'll see come if it happens, probably more along the lines of private label, which is continuing to decline, may be losing some space.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, actually, Amit, let me have that. It's Marty. Look, we're really -- first of all, we're really pleased with the trajectory of Packaged Beverages operating margins up again I think about 100 basis points year-over-year. And your right, on an overall s
componenttext: Yes, actually, Amit, let me have that. It's Marty. Look, we're really -- first of all, we're really pleased with the trajectory of Packaged Beverages operating margins up again I think about 100 basis points year-over-year. And your right, on an overall segment basis, the allied brands actually went down a little bit. They're still very profitable, but we don't overall average margin. I'll also tell you this just a reminder that listed in our prepared remarks and in the press release, Packaged Beverages took a $4 million nonrecurring hit quite frankly. We put our field people out of the company cars. We made a onetime payment to do that. And we expensed that in the quarter. And also, I'll be honest with you. We -- some of their operating costs are up more than we would expect on a long-term basis and we'll make some investors and our front line. Let of activities going on. It's no secret. Everybody is sort of worried their front-line people, and we're taking care of our front-line people and were spending a lot more money to do that. All of you know me, the runway for RCI improvement is as far as I'm concerned, unlimited. We find more opportunity every single day in this business. And therefore, we're pretty confident that actually packaged beverage margins can still appreciate at some level.

componenttext: Carol, this is Marty. So debt level roughly $2.9 billion is where we have targeted to be, not that we wouldn't raise it for something that necessitated us to do that. It would not be for share repurchases. We're buying our shares out of our free cash flow, which has been and then said in my remarks, pretty healthy and a pretty of increase over prior year. And I don't know. That's pretty much it. I mean, we stated this level for a little bit of a dead. We did raise a little more money. Again, the last year, and reference that we took advantage of the yield curve at the time and did an incremental of $250 million at 30 year, about 4.5% and in asset, that's going into share repurchases this year. If you look at our $650 million to $700 million, it's roughly $250 million higher than our sort of $400 million to $450 million average per year amount. That's simply reflecting that incremental $250 million bar but there's no other plan to significantly change our capital structure.

componenttext: Yes, I mean, digital, in our marketing return on investment work, or as digital shows some of the highest returns. If your question goes to sort of the dollar cost effectiveness of digital, for example, on the traditional TV, yes, you can. But digital, too, is getting pricey as well because everybody is trying to take advantage of it. But there's a lot of the things we're doing in marketing that comes specifically from our marketing return on investment work, which is yielding improved effectiveness on that same level of marketing spend, with that 7.5% of the sales. One of the reasons we feel we need to do more is because we're getting good results moving our TV spots from 30 seconds to 15 seconds depending upon the campaign. All sorts of shifts around between alcohol prime channels and cable channels, programmatic through digital display. There's lots of things we're doing that we're learning from our ROI. Reducing in certain markets traditional out of home, billboards, local radio, there are places where they're effective what we discovered was a process where they are not, and we spent a lot of time working with our marketing folks to analyze this data and shift our moneys where we get this return and it's a very consistent with RCI. That's an area we want to find the ways and we want to redeploy it and slowly but surely, I think we're getting there.

The call and slides will be also available for replay and download after the call has ended. [Operator Instructions]

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Maria, and good morning, everyone. Before we begin, I would like to direct your attention to the safe harbor statement and remind you that this conference call contains forward-looking statements, including statements concerning our financial a
componenttext:
Thank you, Maria, and good morning, everyone. Before we begin, I would like to direct your attention to the safe harbor statement and remind you that this conference call contains forward-looking statements, including statements concerning our financial and operational performance. These forward-looking statements should also be considered in connection with cautionary statements and disclaimers contained in the safe harbor statement in this morning's earnings press release and our SEC filings. Our actual performance could differ materially from these statements, and we undertake no duty to update these forward-looking statements.
During this call, we may reference certain non-GAAP financial measures that reflect the way we evaluate the business and which we believe provide useful information for investors. Reconciliations of those non-GAAP measures to GAAP can be found in our earnings press release and on the Investors page at www.drpeppersnapple.com.
This morning's prepared remarks will be made by Larry Young, President and CEO; and Marty Ellen, our CFO. Following our prepared remarks, we will open the call for your questions.
With that, let me turn the call over to Larry.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Heather, and good morning, everyone. Once again, we posted another solid quarter as our teams continued to relentlessly focus against our strategy. We're on track with driving integrated communications and execution across our priority brands and
componenttext:
Thanks, Heather, and good morning, everyone. Once again, we posted another solid quarter as our teams continued to relentlessly focus against our strategy. We're on track with driving integrated communications and execution across our priority brands and RCI continues to permeate throughout the organization and drive sustainable financial benefits.
For the quarter, bottler case sales increased 1% on almost 4 points of positive mix and price. Volumes grew across our portfolio, with CSDs increasing by 1% and noncarbs increasing by 2%. Brand Dr Pepper decreased 1% in the quarter as continued strong growth in our fountain foodservice business was more than offset by declines in diet. Our Diet Dr Pepper business continues to significantly outperform the diet category, declining at about half the rate of all diets, driven by the strength of our Lil' Sweet campaign.
Our Core 4 brands also declined 1%, as over 5% growth in Canada Dry was more than offset by declines in 7UP, A&W and Sunkist Soda. Crush and Schweppes grew 4% and 9% respectively, on increased activation at a large retailer. Squirt grew 8% on strong growth in both Mexico and the U.S. and Peñafiel grew 4%. All other CSD brands decreased 2% in the quarter.
In noncarbs, Snapple declined 2% as growth from product innovation was more than offset by the effect a year ago of liquidating certain Snapple inventories. As a reminder, Snapple growth in the second quarter last year was 11%. Hawaiian Punch decreased 5%, as expected, driven primarily by price increases on single-serve packages. Mott's was flat in the quarter, as growth in sauce was fully offset by decreases in juice, driven by price increases on single-serve packages. Clamato grew 14% in the quarter, reflecting continued strong growth across Mexico, the U.S. and Canada.
Our water category grew 25% on growth in our allied brand portfolio, particularly Bai and FIJI and continued growth in Aguafiel. All other noncarb brands decreased 10% in the quarter, almost entirely due to our exit of a Country Time business.
Building our brands continue to be a critical element of our overall strategy and success, and we've got another strong calendar programming that is targeted against our consumer insights for the back half of the year. Our regular Dr Pepper 20 ounce program highlights 150 unique labels that allow consumers to choose their favorite bottle that represents their individuality. Though it's early on, we're seeing recent upward trends in our convenient [ph] and gas business, and our consumers are showcasing their love for the bottles on social platforms, such as Instagram and Twitter. You can also even purchase your preferred bottle on eBay.
As I mentioned earlier, our diet Lil' Sweet campaign continues to drive impressive results for the brand and we'll start college football off strong with heavy media across TV and digital platforms and activation in large national accounts. And new this year, Larry Culpepper, will be tailgating across the country to bring Dr Pepper to every football gathering in his own Dr Pepper van. Our Dr Pepper Cherry push is bringing new users into the franchise and consumers are enjoying A&W root beer floats at their summer parties. Core 4 is bringing back monster-themed mini cans for Halloween with an app that will bring the monsters to life on your smart device.
Canada Dry will continue to capitalize on growth in the ale category, with increased media throughout the rest of the year and will activate against Schweppes sparkling waters, honing in on the growing mixture occasion. Snapple will remind consumers to make time for Snapple, with quirky new Real Facts ads and we'll once again bring news to the TO with red, blue election-themed LTOs.
Clamato has partnered with an authentic Mexican beer to spice up outdoor gatherings as the original Michelada. You may have seen our Mott's Secret Life of Pets packaging in the market. And just in time for back-to-school, Mott's will support schools with bonus Box Tops for Education.
As you've seen, we've got a tremendous amount of activity lined up that engages our consumers and gives our customers and partners programs to rally behind.
Now let me turn the call over to Marty to walk you through our financial results and our 2016 guidance.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Larry. Let me start with a high level financial summary of the quarter which, as Larry just said, reflected solid performance.Sales volume increased 1%, with reported net sales up 2%. Core operating income was up 6% and core operating margin was
componenttext:
Thanks, Larry. Let me start with a high level financial summary of the quarter which, as Larry just said, reflected solid performance.
Sales volume increased 1%, with reported net sales up 2%. Core operating income was up 6% and core operating margin was 22.8%, up 70 basis points. Core EPS was up 11% in the quarter. On a currency-neutral basis, net sales were up 4%. Core operating income was up 8% and core EPS was up 12%.
Now let me provide some further details. Reported net sales increased 2% on about 2.5 points of favorable product and package mix, just over 1 percentage point of price realization and a 1% increase in sales volumes. Reducing this net sales growth was just over 1.5 points of foreign currency translation and almost 1 point of unfavorable segment mix, as concentrate sales were relatively higher this year.
Reported gross margins increased 120 basis points in the quarter, increasing from 59.3% last year to 60.5% this year, of which 90 basis points was driven by the favorable effect of unrealized mark-to-market commodity changes. Lower commodity costs, primarily PET and aluminum, increased gross margins by 60 basis points, and continued productivity benefits, including those from RCI as well as certain other packaging and ingredient cost reductions, increased gross margins by another 50 basis points. The impact of positive net pricing also increased gross margins by 50 basis points.
The effect of mix, mostly from products purchased from others, reduced gross margins by 100 basis points. And finally, foreign currency reduced gross margins in the quarter by 30 basis points as Mexico sources certain inputs in U.S. dollars and finished products sold in Canada are sourced from the U.S.
For the quarter, SG&A, excluding depreciation, increased by $4 million on inflationary and certain other increases and operating expenses, including a onetime $4 million cost associated with the transition of a certain employee benefit program. These increases were partially offset by favorable foreign currency translation, a reduction in transportation costs, driven by lower fuel prices and $7 million of lower marketing investments year-over-year due to timing shifts of brand campaigns. Depreciation and amortization declined $2 million in the quarter.
Below the operating line, net interest expense increased $5 million, primarily reflecting overall higher debt balance and higher rates from our fourth quarter 2015 refinancing. Other income increased by $23 million in the quarter as a result of a $21 million gain on the extinguishment of a multiemployer pension plan withdrawal liability. This gain has been excluded from our core results. Our reported effective tax rate was 35.3% compared to 35.5% last year.
Moving on to cash flow. Cash from operating activities was $407 million, net of the $35 million payment of the multiemployer pension plan liability. Cash from operating activities was up $58 million compared to last year, primarily driven by timing of certain working capital amounts and the increase in net income adjusted for noncash items. Capital spending was $68 million compared to $42 million last year as we have spent incrementally to further support our growth in Mexico. Our new mineral water plant north of Mexico City should be operational in the fourth quarter of this year.
For the first 6 months, total distributions to our shareholders were $493 million, with $303 million in shares repurchased and $190 million in dividends paid.
Before I move on to guidance, let me give a quick update on Rapid Continuous Improvement. Our 2016 lean tracks are in full swing. We've already had over 75 Kaizen events across the organization, and we're seeing wins across the board. I'll share a few now. 
In our Orlando DSD site, driver turnover has been reduced by 44%, driven by improved recruiting, on-boarding and performance management processes. Through this lean track nationally, we're also learning from our drivers other elements of waste that will enable us to further improve the effectiveness of our route delivery system. A job role safety playbook, developed by our frontline employees, is driving a 25% recordable injury reduction year-over-year in the second quarter, helping drive 12 months trend rates down almost double digits. We've closed over 2,000 voids on Dr Pepper's smaller CSD packages in a large retailer through a similar process we used to close voids on other brands. And certain allied brands are experiencing both double and triple-digit growth rates, partially as a result of our tracks specifically focused on allied brand distribution and availability. And as I've mentioned before, we have a tremendous amount of RCI activity going on throughout the business in addition to our lean tracks. Branch managers in our central business units gained 10 hours per week of additional customer-facing time by adapting the RCI principle of standard work. And our Mexican team has improved Peñafiel distribution with our third-party distributors by creating standard work for trade management and point-of-sale.
We have great urgency to improve the performance of brand 7UP. Our lean track is under way. And while there is still a great deal of work to do, the team has diligently focused on the components of brand messaging and execution in local markets. Supporting this is a deep inspection of pricing, packaging, channel and geographic competitive trends alongside those of 7UP. These insights should enable us to begin implementing certain changes in the balance of 2016. There is definitely more to come on 7UP. Again, these are just very few examples of the vast improvement initiatives taking place across our entire business everyday.
Now let me move on to 2016 guidance. We continue to expect reported net sales to be up approximately 2%, inclusive of a foreign currency translation headwind of about 1%. Given our first half performance, we are increasing our full year core EPS guidance. We now expect core EPS to be in the $4.27 to $4.35 range. This is inclusive of what we now expect to be about a 3% headwind from both foreign currency translation and transaction combined versus the 2.5% that we had expected previously. We continue to expect total company sales volume to be about flat. Similar to our previous guidance, we expect CSDs to be about flat, while we expect noncarbs to be up slightly. Remember that our noncarb volume performance is being tempered this year by pricing actions taken across several of our Warehouse Direct brands. However, we still expect continued growth from other noncarb brands, such as Snapple, Clamato and our allied brand portfolio.
On a total company basis, we expect combined price and mix to be up about 3%. Our January 1 concentrate price increase will drive about 40 basis points of this increase and price increases on our Warehouse Direct brands will drive an additional 20 basis points. The remainder will come from mix as a result of stronger growth from smaller CSD packages and brands, such as Snapple, Clamato and our allied brand portfolio.
Moving on to cost of goods. Given our hedge positions and current market prices for our unhedged positions, we now expect packaging and ingredients to be about 1% deflationary on a constant volume/mix basis. This expectation still reflects deflation in commodities such as PET and aluminum and, as we have previously said, a headwind on corn, driven primarily by increases in toll-linked fees and unfavorable pricing of corn co-products, from which we derive our net corn price. For modeling purposes, remember that growth from some of our noncarb portfolio and allied brands will also increase the dollar value of cost of goods. And also remember that cost of goods is negatively impacted by foreign currency transaction, as I mentioned a moment ago. Collectively, all the factors I mentioned above should result in roughly similar gross margins in 2016.
Moving to SG&A. We now expect an increase of approximately $15 million in health and welfare and other insurance costs versus the original $20 million that we had previously expected. We also still expect general inflation in our field labor costs to increase operating expenses by approximately $20 million. That said, we believe we will be able to achieve productivity benefits from RCI that will help offset a portion of these increases, and we're also now expecting favorability from lower fuel costs of about $10 million, more than half of which we have already experienced. We continue to expect marketing to be about 7.5% of sales for the year. This implies a significant uptick in the back half of the year, mostly in the third quarter.
Now moving below segment operating profit. Our net interest expense will be around 4.5% on our $2.9 billion of debt, which implies an increase of approximately $15 million, driven primarily by our fourth quarter 2015 debt refinancing. Our full year core tax rate is still expected to be approximately 35.5%, and we continue to expect capital spending to be approximately 3% of net sales, even with the spending for our new plant in Mexico.
We also continue to expect to repurchase approximately $650 million to $700 million of our common stock in 2016, subject to market conditions.
Now let me highlight a couple of additional phasing items that will help you update your models. First, as previously mentioned, while we expect commodities to be deflationary for the full year, the deflation has already been experienced and our trends are expected to turn flat to slightly up for the balance of the year due to the year-over-year timing of a certain commodity-related rebate. And second, based on timing of prior year true-ups, both the third quarter and fourth quarter will experience an increase in health and welfare and other insurance costs.
With that said, let me turn the call back over to Larry.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marty. Before we open the lines for questions, let me leave you with a few brief though consistent thoughts. Once again, we posted solid results in the quarter. We're continuing to focus on driving integrated communication, innovation and executio
componenttext:
Thanks, Marty. Before we open the lines for questions, let me leave you with a few brief though consistent thoughts. Once again, we posted solid results in the quarter. We're continuing to focus on driving integrated communication, innovation and execution across our key priority brands, while also selectively adding to our allied brand portfolio to capture fast-moving consumer trends.
We're continuing to embed RCI further into our culture, and we're seeing meaningful improvements in growth and productivity across the company. And importantly, we remain committed to returning excess free cash to our shareholders over time.
Operator, we're ready for our first question.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Ali Dibadj of Bernstein.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Ali Dibadj of Bernstein.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of things in both on the Packaged Beverages business. Obviously, they're a little bit less than, certainly, we in consensus had it at. And it's attributed to lower contract manufacturing volumes. Can you help us quantify the impact of that?
componenttext: Just a couple of things in both on the Packaged Beverages business. Obviously, they're a little bit less than, certainly, we in consensus had it at. And it's attributed to lower contract manufacturing volumes. Can you help us quantify the impact of that? You mentioned in your comments Country Time. Is it all Country Time? And then I remember, we've heard back -- about this in 2010, 2011, I think, it was roughly. That at that point, you're getting rid of -- or de-emphasizing some of your contract manufacturing. How much more of that is left? And I think that both from a volume impact perspective, but also from a potential improving your margins in that segment.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ali, this is Marty. So contract manufacturing volume was down a little bit in the quarter, probably had an overall impact of maybe 1 point on overall volume in Packaged Beverages. I would say, actually, we're not -- as a matter of strategy in terms of hel
componenttext: Ali, this is Marty. So contract manufacturing volume was down a little bit in the quarter, probably had an overall impact of maybe 1 point on overall volume in Packaged Beverages. I would say, actually, we're not -- as a matter of strategy in terms of helping us use excess capacity in our plants, it's still our strategy. Business comes and goes in that arena. There are competitors there. And it's very geographic. We're only going to be effective dealing with retailers on their private label, for example, in the geographies where our plants are, and assuming those plants have the capacity to do their volumes. Otherwise, transportation makes it sort of a nonstarter. And we're still going to aggressively pursue volumes in our plants where it makes sense to do so. At the same time, we still do some co-packing around the energy category, and that business continues.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So -- okay, so this is not as it was in 2010, 2011 when you were getting rid of less profitable businesses. This is just the tides sometime of business in that sector. That's what it sounds like.
componenttext: So -- okay, so this is not as it was in 2010, 2011 when you were getting rid of less profitable businesses. This is just the tides sometime of business in that sector. That's what it sounds like.

componenttext: That's like a lot of our -- as we bring on these allied brands, when we first bring them in, a lot of them have agreements already with some people on the contract pack. As it's available and makes sense, we always look at it. We have great relationships with all our allied brands and we always look at it together and say if we can -- if it makes sense for us to do it, we'll look at it. If not, we're fine with the arrangements we have right now.

componenttext: Let me give some color on the -- so across all of our allied brands, the entire portfolio, this quarter, I would tell you, they collectively were less than 2% of our volume and less than 4% of our SOP in total for all of them. If you're curious as to like case growth rates, there was probably $0.5 million total cases of growth in there -- $0.5 million to $1 million case of total growth in there year-over-year in the second quarter.

componenttext: There's stuff in the press out there about how much you own. Can you give us a little bit more detail about how much of this company you own? It doesn't sound like it's a majority stake in any stretch of imagination. Press stuff suggests kind of low single-digit type ownership. Can you give us anything about how to think about the protection you actually have in the ownership stakes?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The percentages we own are small, but we also have  -- it contracts, and there's -- we have buyouts and certain things like that. We don't ever disclose all of them put together, but we continue to feel very protected on those. But I think the biggest thi
componenttext: The percentages we own are small, but we also have  -- it contracts, and there's -- we have buyouts and certain things like that. We don't ever disclose all of them put together, but we continue to feel very protected on those. But I think the biggest thing that protects us is the performance we do for them. I mean, if you look at the kind of growth we're getting there and the relationships we have, I don't think we will lose too much sleep. I mean, it could happen, but if it does, we're covered. It's happened in the past, and we've always recovered. We brought something else in, that's why we constantly look at them.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ali, it's Marty. Let me go back to -- and looking at the numbers. So the growth -- probably worth 0.5 point of growth this quarter. I may have understated the number a little bit. But let me follow on Larry's point. We've talked hopefully about the strate
componenttext: Ali, it's Marty. Let me go back to -- and looking at the numbers. So the growth -- probably worth 0.5 point of growth this quarter. I may have understated the number a little bit. But let me follow on Larry's point. We've talked hopefully about the strategy and at some point, given all these companies are run by entrepreneurs, the successful launch we'll look to monetize at some point, that's not a secret. As I've said before, we have a long pipeline of opportunities. In fact, I'll be headed to a meeting right after this call to do a review of that again. And of course, monetarily, we have small pieces of equity and, of course, filed agreements in our distribution agreements with our --  which is worth a reasonable sum of money, should we lose the distribution. Don't -- I don't want anybody on this call to think that because 1 or more of these may change hands, that we necessarily lose the distribution either. There aren't too many other companies -- there are a couple, but not many more that have the platform that we have in terms of our coverage and our relationships and our ability to work with the other large bottlers that are part of our network. So as Larry said, we bring a lot of value to them, and we think there's a lot of future opportunity given some of the brands that we're now seeing presenting themselves to us to do similar kinds of distribution activities with.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Steve Powers of UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Steve Powers of UBS.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of quick ones, if I could. First, on fountain. Second, on 7UP. Just -- the fountain business is running a good bit ahead year-to-date of your historical growth. I'm just curious as to whether we should expect that to continue in the second half o
componenttext: A couple of quick ones, if I could. First, on fountain. Second, on 7UP. Just -- the fountain business is running a good bit ahead year-to-date of your historical growth. I'm just curious as to whether we should expect that to continue in the second half or should we expect sort of a correction or normalization in the back half. And then on 7UP, as you called out the RCI initiatives to improve that, is that something we should expect to see some movement on in the second half? Or is that 2017?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, it's Marty. Let me talk about 7UP. We're doing a lot of work, as I've said. We're finding some insights. My comment earlier about the phasing of marketing, 7UP is part of that because through our strategy work and our consumer insight work, we are
componenttext: Steve, it's Marty. Let me talk about 7UP. We're doing a lot of work, as I've said. We're finding some insights. My comment earlier about the phasing of marketing, 7UP is part of that because through our strategy work and our consumer insight work, we are changing the messaging on the brand and that's going to roll out in the second half. And you'll see probably some activation. You may not see them, but the market will see some changes in activation at retail. There are some new and different thoughts that have arisen that we're going to try here in the second half of the year. It's a lot of work in progress. We're encouraged by it. Obviously, it is the weak spot in the Core 4; everything else, actually, is performing fairly well. So more to come on that. I can't remember what the first half of the question was.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The fountain business.
componenttext: The fountain business.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, fountain. Look, we've done reasonably well in fountain. We've had historic growth rates 1% to 2% for a while. We continue to gain valves. Our team is doing a good job. We're increasingly selling in the regional strength of our brands, as all of you k
componenttext: Yes, fountain. Look, we've done reasonably well in fountain. We've had historic growth rates 1% to 2% for a while. We continue to gain valves. Our team is doing a good job. We're increasingly selling in the regional strength of our brands, as all of you know, in regions of the country. That's an advantage for us. And the Freestyle business that we have with Coke has -- seem to improve and so we're selling more syrup into cartridges going to Freestyle machines. But that's, of course, good for Dr Pepper.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, okay. And then just stepping back, in May, we had -- the FDA announced new package food and beverage label requirements, with more focus on both calorie disclosures as well as, importantly, the added sugar disclosures. Just given your portfolio skewi
componenttext: Yes, okay. And then just stepping back, in May, we had -- the FDA announced new package food and beverage label requirements, with more focus on both calorie disclosures as well as, importantly, the added sugar disclosures. Just given your portfolio skewing towards full calorie CSDs and full sugar beverages generally, I'm just curious how you're approaching that change? And do you have any clarity on the time line to implement it? And then, any guesses on the impacts to your business? Any mitigation efforts you're dealing, whether it be more accelerated portfolio shifts or more accelerated investments in smaller pack sizes, that kind of things? Just how are you thinking about the pending changes?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, on the changes, I mean, we will follow the guidelines. And as far as the sweetened beverages, we've been seeing growth come back into the sugared beverages. So I don't see us changing anything there. I think we're just glad to see that it's going to
componenttext: Well, on the changes, I mean, we will follow the guidelines. And as far as the sweetened beverages, we've been seeing growth come back into the sugared beverages. So I don't see us changing anything there. I think we're just glad to see that it's going to be more of a federal labeling instead of having 20 different ones out there, where it really drives the cost up of packaging and then distribution. So we were happy with that. And we think the FDA and our guys all did a great job there on helping get that through. But I don't see any significant impacts that I'm too concerned about them.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Does that -- does it roll into the market in the second half or is that 2017?
componenttext: Does that -- does it roll into the market in the second half or is that 2017?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's going to be later in 2017.
componenttext: I think it's going to be later in 2017.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Judy Hong of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Judy Hong of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So first, on Snapple, just wanted to get a little bit more color just in terms of how much did the inventory issue impact volume in the quarter. And then maybe taking a step back, Snapple obviously has been a pretty good growth driver for you guys. And ke
componenttext: So first, on Snapple, just wanted to get a little bit more color just in terms of how much did the inventory issue impact volume in the quarter. And then maybe taking a step back, Snapple obviously has been a pretty good growth driver for you guys. And key categories seems to be growing, but the consumers seem to be trading up to more of a premium tea, and Snapple seems to be lagging the category growth a little bit. So just wanted to better understand what the strategy is to kind of accelerate Snapple's growth going forward.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, as I said in my remarks, we've got a lot of good new advertising we're doing with Snapple. We've got more LTOs laid out. The quarter, again, like I said, was up 11% a year ago, and then we had some inventories we had to move because we've bee
componenttext: Yes, I mean, as I said in my remarks, we've got a lot of good new advertising we're doing with Snapple. We've got more LTOs laid out. The quarter, again, like I said, was up 11% a year ago, and then we had some inventories we had to move because we've been telling people all along we started de-emphasizing the value so there was a lot of factors for the second quarter that made the difference on that. I think you'll see going forward with the programs we have in place that Snapple will get more of a clearer message out there of what Snapple is and where we play and what -- with what the consumer wants. I don't know if everybody's really trading up to a premium or it's kind of -- you've got flavored teas out there [indiscernible] teas, and I think that's the big place where you're seeing kind of the shifts. We see a lot of the tea drinkers, so if we have Straight Up Tea, but they don't take anything away from the Snapple drinker. That flavored drinker on Snapple and flavored teas, they like that flavor, they're going to stay there. So we continue with our strategy on our flavored teas and our Snapple juices, and then we continue for distribution out there on our Straight Up Tea.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, Larry, in just kind of looking at the broader CSD kind of shelf space. And obviously, with the category, I think, it's seeing a bit of a decline in terms of shelf space, kind of broadly over the last few years. You obviously have many bran
componenttext: Okay. And then, Larry, in just kind of looking at the broader CSD kind of shelf space. And obviously, with the category, I think, it's seeing a bit of a decline in terms of shelf space, kind of broadly over the last few years. You obviously have many brands in the portfolio, and some brands like 7UP, that's declining in terms of volume. So just wanted to understand kind of how do you protect that shelf space. And then when you think about like maybe Monster launching Newton in the CSD space and what that implication could be in terms of particularly in the C stores as you think about protecting your own shelf space there.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, one, we're not losing any shelf space, and I think what really helps us there, Judy, is when you look at -- we're #1 ginger ale, #1 root beer. I mean, if we're not #1, #2, we don't even have it on the shelves out here. So I mean, we do a very g
componenttext: Yes, well, one, we're not losing any shelf space, and I think what really helps us there, Judy, is when you look at -- we're #1 ginger ale, #1 root beer. I mean, if we're not #1, #2, we don't even have it on the shelves out here. So I mean, we do a very good job on our accounts with category management for the account, but our brands carry the weight there for us. So we're fine there. I think on the -- you brought up for Monster -- not just Monster, but a lot of these brands always come out and they try to get in different places and they've not been very successful at it. I mean, there's been ones that will want to get into coffee, they will want to get into dairy, they want to get into the juice aisle, they want to get into the CSD aisle. But most of the retailers, most of our customers want them in a block. They keep them in the same area. And so we'll have to watch it, but we're not that concerned with it. We think we'll see -- if it happens, that'll probably be more along the lines of private label, which is continuing to decline, maybe losing some space.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Amit Sharma of BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Amit Sharma of BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: Larry, I just wanted to talk about the North American CSD pricing. We've seen at least the can channels start to lose some stream there and pricing was -- are you seeing anything different? I'm specifically talking about some of the markets where Coke has refranchised recently, are you seeing any pricing activity there? Or change in how pricing has been in those markets?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're seeing pricing as flat. I think before, we might have seen a little shift in mix and some different things with packages, but pricing's flat. And so that's not a bad thing. I think there's still a tremendous amount of discipline out there. And we do
componenttext: We're seeing pricing as flat. I think before, we might have seen a little shift in mix and some different things with packages, but pricing's flat. And so that's not a bad thing. I think there's still a tremendous amount of discipline out there. And we don't see any reason that would change.

componenttext: And no change in recently refranchised markets?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, good. And then a question on the margin trajectory of the Packaged Beverage business. I mean, you talked about single-serve and you talked about even the premiumization of some categories. Is this current trajectory of margin improvement -- and unde
componenttext: Okay, good. And then a question on the margin trajectory of the Packaged Beverage business. I mean, you talked about single-serve and you talked about even the premiumization of some categories. Is this current trajectory of margin improvement -- and understanding that allied brands probably weighed down on that a little bit -- is this the right trajectory? Or should we expect it a little bit stronger as we go along this path?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Actually -- let me handle that. It's Marty. Look, we're really -- first of all, we're really pleased with the trajectory of Packaged Beverages. Operating margins up again this year, I think about 100 basis points year-over-year. And you're right, on an ov
componenttext: Actually -- let me handle that. It's Marty. Look, we're really -- first of all, we're really pleased with the trajectory of Packaged Beverages. Operating margins up again this year, I think about 100 basis points year-over-year. And you're right, on an overall segment basis, the allied brands actually weighed it down a little, but -- they're still very profitable, but weighed down the overall average margin. I will also tell you, just want to remind you that we said in our prepared remarks and on the press release, don't forget Packaged Beverages took a $4 million nonrecurring hit. Quite frankly, we took our field people out of their company cars. We made a onetime payment to do that. And we expensed that in the quarter. And also, I'll be honest with you, we -- some of the operating costs are up more than we would expect on a long-term basis and we're make some investments in our front line. Lots of activities going on. It's no secret. Everybody's sort of worried about their front line people, and we're taking care of our front line people and we're spending a little more money to do that. All of you know me, the runway for RCI improvement is, as far as I'm concerned, unlimited. We find more opportunity every single day in this business. And therefore, we're pretty confident that actually Packaged Beverage margins can still appreciate at some level.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: We've not seen anything significant, no.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to follow up, please, on the commentary around 7UP in the evaluation that you're doing, and you called out pricing is 1 lever that you would be inspecting. I'm curious if you can expand on that a little bit just given how narrow price gaps are in
componenttext: I wanted to follow up, please, on the commentary around 7UP in the evaluation that you're doing, and you called out pricing is 1 lever that you would be inspecting. I'm curious if you can expand on that a little bit just given how narrow price gaps are in the category more broadly.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Vivien, what my -- point of my comment was it's everything: it's pricing, it's packaging, it's channel. There's nothing specific, per se, that we're going to call out in terms of pricing in a market, in a package. But we're looking at overall how the bran
componenttext: Vivien, what my -- point of my comment was it's everything: it's pricing, it's packaging, it's channel. There's nothing specific, per se, that we're going to call out in terms of pricing in a market, in a package. But we're looking at overall how the brand performs, the elasticity, the historic data on elasticities and what we think about current elasticities. And so we think about, all the time, balancing price; share with regard to, for example, protecting our space; and but big time profitability, okay? So there's nothing there -- there's no -- let me lay it out [ph] for you. There's no strategy here to sort of lower pricing 7UP as a way to grow the brand. That's the last thing we're going to do.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's not sustainable and you just [indiscernible] volume when you do it with price.
componenttext: Yes, that's not sustainable and you just [indiscernible] volume when you do it with price.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that seems reasonable enough. My next question has to do with diet. It's certainly encouraging that you guys are outperforming the industry, but given how many years you're into this outsized decline in diets, I was wondering whether you have any up
componenttext: Okay, that seems reasonable enough. My next question has to do with diet. It's certainly encouraging that you guys are outperforming the industry, but given how many years you're into this outsized decline in diets, I was wondering whether you have any updated thoughts on that, just given that we're continuing to see the volume base shrink. Is there a mix in terms of where that volume bleed is coming from? Do we continue to lose consumers? Is it -- I mean, I'm sure it's a balance between losing consumers and reductions in per capita consumption, but has that balance shifted at all over the last few years as the declines persist?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Like I said, we're outperforming the category but I don't think we're losing consumers. I mean, if you look at all the -- our broad portfolio, especially with our allied brands, we have some people that are going over to some of our allied brands, some of
componenttext: Like I said, we're outperforming the category but I don't think we're losing consumers. I mean, if you look at all the -- our broad portfolio, especially with our allied brands, we have some people that are going over to some of our allied brands, some of out better-for-yous, some of the diet brands in there. I think we will continue our Lil' Sweet campaign because we're seeing it get momentum. And so I think we will find the bottom of where it's at with Dr Pepper. I think if you look at -- if you break the diet category down, this category's losing much more, much more of the volumes. So I think we're going to get it, but I still think some of our consumers, as we continue our insights, we're not losing them. There's switchers, they're going to other brands and we're keeping them in our portfolio.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful, but then -- but within diet for those consumers that are just kind of leaving, are you also seeing reductions in per capita consumption? Or is this really more of a migration to other pieces of your portfolio?
componenttext: That's helpful, but then -- but within diet for those consumers that are just kind of leaving, are you also seeing reductions in per capita consumption? Or is this really more of a migration to other pieces of your portfolio?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've not really seen it. Households are still holding up, household penetration. The per caps are still there. I think you just got some with concerns about the sweeteners that are -- now they're going to something else. And your diet drinkers are some o
componenttext: We've not really seen it. Households are still holding up, household penetration. The per caps are still there. I think you just got some with concerns about the sweeteners that are -- now they're going to something else. And your diet drinkers are some of the most loyal consumers you'll ever see on their diet brands.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, lastly, is there any way to sort of like disaggregate your growth between like same-store sales and distribution gains? Because I know, like, when I was out there, you talked a lot about having RCI track on distribution voids. Is that getting de
componenttext: And then, lastly, is there any way to sort of like disaggregate your growth between like same-store sales and distribution gains? Because I know, like, when I was out there, you talked a lot about having RCI track on distribution voids. Is that getting decent traction and are there any big opportunities that could actually move the needle?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Bill, we've made great -- we talked even last year, we've done -- we've closed voids through our sort of lean tracks on Snapple, on Canada Dry. I mentioned a specific activity around Dr Pepper. We look at velocity -- your points of distribution and vel
componenttext: So Bill, we've made great -- we talked even last year, we've done -- we've closed voids through our sort of lean tracks on Snapple, on Canada Dry. I mentioned a specific activity around Dr Pepper. We look at velocity -- your points of distribution and velocity all of the time internally, but there's no way I could share with you, for modeling purposes, how you can model growth, for example, between new points of distribution and velocity from existing points of distribution.
