componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to Dr Pepper Snapple Group's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded and includes a slide presentation, which can be accessed at www.drpeppersnapple.com. The call and slides will also be available for replay and download after the call has ended. [Operator Instructions] It's now my pleasure to introduce Heather Catelotti, Vice President, Investor Relations. Heather, you may begin.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Maria, and good morning, everyone.Before we begin, I would like to direct your attention to the safe harbor statement and remind you that this conference call contains forward-looking statements, including statements concerning our future fin
componenttext:
Thank you, Maria, and good morning, everyone.
Before we begin, I would like to direct your attention to the safe harbor statement and remind you that this conference call contains forward-looking statements, including statements concerning our future financial and operational performance. These statements should also be considered in connection with cautionary statements and disclaimers contained in the safe harbor statement in this morning's earnings press release and our SEC filings. Our actual performance could differ materially from these statements, and we undertake no duty to update these forward-looking statements.
During this call, we may reference certain non-GAAP financial measures that reflect the way we evaluate the business and which we believe provide useful information for investors. Reconciliations of those non-GAAP measures to GAAP can be found in our earnings press release and on the Investors page at www.drpeppersnapple.com.
This morning's prepared remarks will be made by Larry Young, President and CEO; and Marty Ellen, our CFO. Following our prepared remarks, we will open the call for your questions. With that, I'll turn the call over to Larry.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Heather, and good morning, everyone. Our third quarter results continued to demonstrate progress in our strategic initiatives. We stayed focused against our strategy of driving integrated communication and execution across our priority, trademark
componenttext:
Thanks, Heather, and good morning, everyone. Our third quarter results continued to demonstrate progress in our strategic initiatives. We stayed focused against our strategy of driving integrated communication and execution across our priority, trademark brands. And it is driving good results. We continue to expense growth in the quarter from our allied brand partnerships and we continue to build our culture of continuous improvement with meaningful results.
For the quarter, bottler case sales increased 2%, on 3-points of positive mix in price. CSD volumes increased by 2% and noncarbs were flat. Brand Dr Pepper increased 1% in the quarter, as we experienced continued strong growth in our fountain foodservice business, as well as growth in our bottled can business. Regular Dr Pepper continue to perform well and Diet Dr Pepper continued to significantly outperform the diet category, growing by almost 1% in the quarter.
Our Core 4 brands increased 2%, as 10% growth in Canada Dry and 1% growth in Sunkist were partially offset by a 2% decline in A&W and a 1% decline in 7UP. Many of you know that we have had a lean track solely focus on 7UP and we are encouraged by the results of this past quarter.
Crush and Schweppes grew 4% and 9% respectively, and Squirt grew 7% in strong growth in both Mexico and the U.S. Peñafiel, grew 1% in the face of increased competition, particularly against our AIDS line. All of the CSDs decreased 3% in the quarter.
In noncarbs, Snapple was flat, cycling 5% growth a year ago, Hawaiian Punch decreased 6% in the quarter, on decreased promotional activity and singleserve price increases. And Mott's declined 6% as well as category headwind is driving declines in dues more than offset growth from our sauce business. Clamato grew 5% in the quarter, and our water category grew 16% on growth on our allied brand portfolio, particularly Bai and FIJI, and continued growth in Aguafiel.
We chose to acquire our Aguafiel partnership interest in Mexico, rather than liquidate the venture because we believe that on our own, we can further improve the performance of the brand. All other noncarb brands decreased 9% in the quarter, almost entirely due to our exit of the Country Time business. This decline was partially offset by strong growth in BODYARMOR, another allied brand, which is continuing to grow share in the sports drink category.
Unlocking growth in our priority brands through strong communication continues to be critical to driving our business results. Our marketing calendar for the balance of the year and the increased margin investment of third quarter reflects just that. We're in the heart of college football season and once again Dr Pepper is front and center. We got heavy media across both TV and several digital platforms and increased activation at retail year-over-year.
New this year, Larry Culpepper will be tailgating across the country and his own Dr Pepper brand, to bring the brand to countless football gatherings. In fact, Larry has become such a popular icon to the brand that we began selling Larry Culpepper Halloween costumes this year and to no surprise, they were sold out in a matter of weeks. We've even spotted a view being listed on eBay for $75 apiece. And then in just 2 days, we'll be taking over student sections by feeding the Larry costumes across a multitude of college campuses during the games.
Also new this year, 7UP and Canada Dry will be both on TV and digital platforms during the holiday season supporting our green bottle program. And Core 4 is bringing back Monster themed mini cans for Halloween with an app that will bring the monsters to life on your smart device. We'll continue to drive retail activation against Schweppes sparkling waters honing in on the mix occasion for the holidays. And Snapple is reminding consumers to take a break from the election with tea season, our red and blue fruit election themed LTO.
I thank you can see our marketing calendar in this year very strong. Now I'll turn the call over to Marty to walk you through our financial results and our updated guidance.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Larry. Good morning, everyone. I'll start by providing a high-level financial summary for the quarter. Sales volume increased 1% with reported net sales up 3%. On a currency neutral basis, net sales were up 4%. Core operating income was up 5% and
componenttext:
Thanks, Larry. Good morning, everyone. I'll start by providing a high-level financial summary for the quarter. Sales volume increased 1% with reported net sales up 3%. On a currency neutral basis, net sales were up 4%. Core operating income was up 5% and core operating margin was 21.7%, up 40 basis points. Core EPS was up 8% in the quarter and it was up 9% on a currency neutral basis.
Now let me provide some further details. Reported net sales increased included 2 points of favorable product and package mix, one percentage point of price realization and a 1% increase in sales volumes. Reducing this net sales growth was 1 point of foreign currency translation.
Reported gross margin increased 60 basis points in the quarter, increasing from 58.7% last year to 59.3% this year. 70 basis points of this improvement was driven by the favorable comparison of unrealized mark-to-market commodity price changes. Positive net pricing, including a favorable trade spend adjustment on our Packaged Beverages segment, increased gross margins by 50 basis points.
Lower commodity costs and continued productivity benefits including those from RCI as well as certain other input cost reductions increased gross margins by 30 basis points each. The impact of mix, mostly from our allied brands, as expected, reduced gross margins by 80 basis points. And inflationary increases in certain other manufacturing costs and increased depreciation decreased gross margins by 30 basis points.
Finally, foreign currency reduced gross margins in the quarter by 20 basis points, principally as Mexico sources certain inputs in U.S. dollars.
For the quarter, reported SG&A, excluding depreciation, rose by $11 million after a $6 million foreign currency translation benefit, marketing as planned, increased $15 million, reflecting new priority brand creatives across several of our trademarks. While we did experience certain inflationary cost increases, these were mostly offset by lower transportation costs driven by lower fuel prices.
Depreciation and amortization declined $2 million. Other income increased by $5 million as a result of a noncash gain on the step acquisition accounting of our Aguafiel joint venture in Mexico. We chose to acquire our partner's interest for $15 million, funded with cash in the joint venture.
Below the operating line, net interest expense increased $4 million, primarily reflecting an overall higher debt balance and higher rates from our fourth quarter 2015 refinancing. Our reported effective tax rate was 29.7% in the quarter, and includes a $17 million gain associated with a legal entity restructuring. Reported effective tax rate in the prior year was 34.4%.
Moving on to cash flow. Cash from operating activities was $683 million, down $40 million compared to last year, primarily due to the $35 million payment of the multi-employer pension plan liability. Capital spending was $110 million compared to $71 million last year. For the first 9 months, total distributions to our shareholders were $748 million, with $460 million in shares repurchased and $288 million in dividends paid.
Before I move on to guidance, let me give a quick update on RCI. You heard me mention many times that we not only utilized the tools and principles of RCI to drive productivity, but also to drive top line growth. Our 2016 lean tracks reflect the balance of the 2 and tackled several of our largest identified opportunities across the organization and to date, we're seeing strong successes. For example, our web sales can recently refind the void reporting process and closed 98% of their execution voids across regular Dr Pepper smaller CSD packages.
With regards to our allied brand portfolio, an SKU prioritization lean activity resulted in distribution and availability growth on priority SKUs by 42%. Our lean track focus on improving processes effecting our route delivery drivers drove a 17% reduction in turn over year-on-year during the summer selling season. And our lost time injuries are down 32% year-on-year, showing a significant improvement in the most severe injuries as a result of our relentless focus on safety and development of our safety playbooks.
And as I mentioned last quarter, we've been very focused on improving the performance of 7UP, and have a separate lean track dedicated to the brand. While we are not declaring success and still have a great deal of work to do on the brand, we are very encouraged by the recent improvement in trends. As you can see, we continue to engage our people across all 5 pillars of RCI: Safety, quality, delivery, productivity and growth.
Now, moving to our updated 2016 guidance. We continue to expect reported net sales to be up approximately 2%, inclusive of a foreign currency translation headwind of about 1%. Given our year-to-date performance, we are increasing our full year core EPS guidance. We now expect core EPS to be in the range of $4.32 to $4.40. This is still inclusive of an expected 3% headwind from both currency translation and transaction combined. We continue to expect total company sales volume to be about flat with CSDs about flat and noncarbs up slightly. We also continue to expect combined price and mix to be up about 3%.
Moving on to cost of goods. We continue to expect packaging and ingredient to be about 1% deflationary on a constant volume/mix basis, which has already been realized. For modeling purposes, remember that growth from some of our noncarb portfolio and allied brands will also increase the dollar value of cost of goods. And also remember that cost of goods is negatively impacted by foreign currency transaction as I mentioned a moment ago. Collectively, all the factors I just mentioned should result in roughly similar gross margins for all of 2016.
Moving to SG&A. We now expect an increase of approximately $5 million in health and welfare and other insurance costs, versus the $15 million that we had previously expected, and we have already experienced this increase. We also still expect general inflation in our field labor costs to increase operating expenses by approximately $20 million for the year. We also continue to invest in execution across our business and are forecasting additional investment of about $3 million in our frontline employees in the fourth quarter. That said, we believe we will be able to achieve productivity benefits from RCI that will help offset a portion of these increases. And we continue to expect favorability from lower fuel costs. We continue to expect marketing to be about 7.5% of sales for the full year, which implies an increase in the fourth quarter.
Now moving below segment operating profit, our net interest expense will be approximately $12 million higher, driven primarily by our fourth quarter 2015 debt refinancing. Our full year core tax rate is now expected to be approximately 35% and we continue to expect capital spending to be approximately 3% of net sales, including the spending for our new plant in Mexico.
We also continue to expect to repurchase approximately $650 million to $700 million of our common stock in 2016, subject to market conditions.
With that, let me turn the call back over to Larry.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marty. Before we open the lines for questions, let me leave you with a few thoughts. We continue to drive strong results across the business. We're focused on driving aligned communication and execution across our priority brands, while also selec
componenttext:
Thanks, Marty. Before we open the lines for questions, let me leave you with a few thoughts. We continue to drive strong results across the business. We're focused on driving aligned communication and execution across our priority brands, while also selectively adding to our allied brand portfolio in an effort to compete in fast growing categories. We're continuing to embed RCI further into our culture. And importantly, we remain committed to returning excess free cash to our shareholders over time.
Operator, we're ready for our first question.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Dara Mohsenian of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Dara Mohsenian of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in the past, you guys have sounded really skeptical with regards to M&A your ability to drive shareholder value through acquisition, just given the high multiples in the industry, I was hoping you could just give us a bit of an update on your thoughts
componenttext: So in the past, you guys have sounded really skeptical with regards to M&A your ability to drive shareholder value through acquisition, just given the high multiples in the industry, I was hoping you could just give us a bit of an update on your thoughts on M&A if anything has changed in your thinking, particularly given what seeing high-growth companies, both in your allied portfolio as well as outside, sustained success over time, so that may be makes you a bit more comfortable with industry valuation levels. But was just hoping for an update there.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dara, it's Marty, I'll make some comments and Larry can add anything if he wants. So I would say, this question goes to directly one of the things we talked about, in terms of risk in our allied brand portfolio is, what happens when if one of these brands
componenttext: Dara, it's Marty, I'll make some comments and Larry can add anything if he wants. So I would say, this question goes to directly one of the things we talked about, in terms of risk in our allied brand portfolio is, what happens when if one of these brands sold new brands, I think, we're really comfortable with the strategy itself, and the ability of through allied brand partners to move quickly with the consumer, to innovate quickly, and to do it in a way, at least at the front end that requires little hard capital, it does require work to execute. You know clearly, we've always said that it's not about if it's more about when the success will want to decide do something with a company, these are all startups, these are all entrepreneurial red businesses, and you know our view is whatever we do, whatever we should do is going to be done in a disciplined way and you may mentioned there is something just now, always been around a while, know that there are a handful of precedent transactions in this industry that I think will all characterize having been done at very large multiple. Everyone conformed their own conclusion. I think you know some of those brands whether or not made hindsight those ended up being successful or not. But we want to be very disciplined. You know that -- those precedent transactions clearly drive many entrepreneurs to do exactly what they are going to be creative, to innovate and we like that, and we're partnered with a number of them and a number of these brands are showing some very early signs of success. Now we can't and are not in control of what these brand owners decide, they want to do with the companies when they want to do it, how they want to do it. I think what's fair to say as a major distributor of these brands, we would be aware if something were happening. But look, and we also understand that whether or not the very high levels of growth can be sustained over a long enough period of time, obviously carries risks. Whether or not brand that start in a certain category can actually be extendable early in their life to other categories is challenge able. And so we're mindful of this and we never forget about competition. You've seen plenty of examples in different categories when others see somebody being successful, you draw a competition and we know we've seen exposures in categories. You can look to sparkling water for example, what I did today versus what it was painfully the category still growing strongly. So we think about these things carefully. We will never say never but we're going to be careful and cautious.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks. That's very helpful. And then the second question is I was hoping if you could give us an update on the pricing environment of what you're seeing in the marketplace for a promotional and this pricing standpoint. And as we look going forward, if co

Or does the current run rate more of a normalized level, even if commodities reinflate? And last, just can you just touch on how hedge you are for inputs as you look out to 2017?

componenttext: I'll take the first part of that, I think everybody seems pricing has been very disciplined. We're not seeing anything out in the market that gives us any angst. It's very disciplined, it's very thought out how the promotions are being ran. I think promotional activity, of course, to some of your always steps up a little bit with the holidays. And I think where the pricing is today if we saw any movement in commodities, I mean, we still have to look at it and say we go where the market this. We have to be competitive and so you know, as we've always told you in the past and we don't always put a lot in the on pricing.

componenttext: And on the part of the question that goes to hedging. We're in a similar position to where we've been in prior years or '17 at this time of year. So what we think we're in a good position going to '07 to, we obviously, give more color on that and cost of goods trends when we talk on our February call.

componenttext: Nik, I'll answer on the Canada Dry, probably not such the second one there. On Canada Dry, if you look at the ginger ale category is doing fantastic. And so with the leader in the category and we put together a lot of new media. You know we went through our return on margin investment, we know which way to advertise now, whether it's shorter television or more going towards the digital and where to play in digital. Then of course, our consumer centric strategy is telling us where that consumer is and we're listening to the consumer, we want the location and we're there. We have a product there. So you're correct, it's on a tear, and we expect it to continue that way.

componenttextpreview: Judy, I think if you go back to my prepared remarks, it's all driven by Mott's and Hawaiian Punch. Mott's, is the pacing headwinds there. We're not surprised that. We had great growth with our sauce but not enough to overcome what we had on the juice decl
componenttext: Judy, I think if you go back to my prepared remarks, it's all driven by Mott's and Hawaiian Punch. Mott's, is the pacing headwinds there. We're not surprised that. We had great growth with our sauce but not enough to overcome what we had on the juice decline. Hawaiian Punch, with a conscious decision, we took pricing. That category too has got some headwinds but we took pricing's especially on our singleserve and that drove it. You take those 2 out and like Marty said earlier, our allied brands again where continuing to grow from about the same as last quarter. Snapple was flat this quarter but it was against some activity we had last year and we just had activity coming up that now that I mentioned is going up levers that. It will be coming back. So those are the 2 that really drove that. So it wasn't a surprise to us. We consciously to the pricing on Hawaiian Punch and I think we'll see, hopefully, we see some improvement next quarter.

And then for the full year guidance, so obviously, the sales and the cost of goods component don't seem to have changed, so when you sort of bridge from the prior earnings guidance to the current guidance, it seems like most of the drivers really on health care costs coming in lower, maybe a little bit of a tax rate being more favorable. And then on the marketing side, it sounds like you're still kind of favorable year-to-date, so $90 million, I think reduction in the first half and $60 million in the third quarter, so should we expect the first 4 quarters to see another step up in terms of the marketing?

componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, in marketing, absolutely. We have not -- the timing during year, as I thank you know and everybody knows was all about as basically going back and redoing a lot of our trademark creative to align with all the work we did in the prior y
componenttext: Well, first of all, in marketing, absolutely. We have not -- the timing during year, as I thank you know and everybody knows was all about as basically going back and redoing a lot of our trademark creative to align with all the work we did in the prior year on our consumer centric strategy. We will have an increase in marketing for the year. It's going to be in the back half, these $15 million or so in this quarter and you're good to see another increase in the fourth quarter. So we like our marketing plans, we like what we're doing, and we think it's actually contributing quite a bit to our top line improvement. So in terms of the guidance, yes, there something's disorder that fell through. You mentioned the tax rate, our tax rate driven by that gain on the joint venture that was a nontaxable gain. That flows through. I'll remind you also that earlier in the year we settled an arbitration award that was awarded against us. Also related to that joint venture. So yes, I mean, we've not -- we've flowed through a few of those things and otherwise, we're sort of where we are.

componenttext: And Bill, it's -- we believe from our own strategy and feedback from consumers that any of our brands are not extendable from their current space. Dr Pepper is an indulgent occasion. Our consumers said don't try to make the Dr Pepper better for me, changing the formulation, changing the sweeteners system but yet you have consumers that are at times, you do want to have a better view occasion. And that's where the growth is, and that's as I said earlier, there's lots of incentive for startups and entrepreneurs to go there to see the opportunity and when they come to us, I think I've shared with all of you, we have a pretty rigid checklists of requirement that passed through the gates here in terms of the brand, the strategy, how they see the consumer versus our consumer insights the credibility of the management team, their access to capital, we do not want to fund these businesses early on and yet they have to have the capital to do what the brand owner needs to do early on, particularly in sales and marketing and you know, look, I'll tell you the pipeline is pretty full and many times, we talked about limiting how many we want to actually get serious with, just simply because we worry about our ability to execute too many and too short a time frame. It's an interesting list of products that are in the energy space and obviously, the enhanced water space. The maple syrup or something water, I'm not sure what that even is, I don't look anything first on us some of the somewhere. You see all these brands. You'll see them from time to time in various places in the markets, particularly in New York. And so we like this path, we like this path to innovation.

componenttext: I guess, I have a question on the innovation, I guess I couldn't help but notice that this year's that a lot of your innovation seems to be focused on allied brands, and it seems there's less of a focus on major innovation behind your own portfolio than perhaps in prior years. So I was hoping you could talk a little bit more broadly about this and how full your innovation pipeline is for your own brands versus your plan to rely more on the step up innovation on allied brands in the future?

componenttextpreview: Well, Bonnie, Larry even mentioned I think in his prepared remarks, innovation about around Snapple. What you should see an are seeing from us when it comes to the brands themselves, you'll see extensions, flavor extensions. Things that allow the brand to
componenttext: Well, Bonnie, Larry even mentioned I think in his prepared remarks, innovation about around Snapple. What you should see an are seeing from us when it comes to the brands themselves, you'll see extensions, flavor extensions. Things that allow the brand to play adjacently to where it is or extend it where it is but not in a different consumer demand space. Now obviously, being at the convenience show, where, of course, the focus is on a lot of single bottle, this is where a lot of the allied brand have opportunities in single bottle, okay, many of them when they come to us is because that's a market channel that fits very well in terms of our ability to distribute versus other larger format channels where they can take their brands in to an essence warehouse to shoot we should model, okay? But yes, everybody knows that single bottle convenience is critically important. So it's not of course, you would see us with a heavy emphasis there, versus -- and it's new versus our traditional brands, but our R&D team is actually growing by a few people next year. They're growing their spending. Lots of work. We continued to do on see retainer technology, that will never stop because it's still important. We're just not trying to extend that innovation to take a brand and treat it, I guess as a name and put it somewhere else where the consumer has said they don't want it. And we're not -- that's our view.

componenttext: You know, Steve, off the top of my head, I mean there's a litany of things in terms of length of TV spots and would they really need 30 seconds versus 15 seconds. So there's and finally could was, I keep forgetting the traditional unpack coupons, real challenge there as to whether that actually gives you in incrementality whatsoever or not. componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Dr Pepper Snapple Group's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded and includes a slide presentation, which can be accessed at www.drpeppersnapple.com. The call and slides will also be available for replay and download after the call has ended. [Operator Instructions]
It is now my pleasure to introduce Heather Catelotti, Vice President, Investor Relations. Heather, you may begin.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Maria, and good morning, everyone.Before we begin, I would like to direct your attention to the safe harbor statement and remind you that this conference call contains forward-looking statements, including statements concerning our future fin
componenttext:
Thank you, Maria, and good morning, everyone.
Before we begin, I would like to direct your attention to the safe harbor statement and remind you that this conference call contains forward-looking statements, including statements concerning our future financial and operational performance. These statements should also be considered in connection with cautionary statements and disclaimers contained in the safe harbor statement in this morning's earnings press release and our SEC filings. Our actual performance could differ materially from these statements, and we undertake no duty to update these forward-looking statements.
During this call, we may reference certain non-GAAP financial measures that reflect the way we evaluate the business and which we believe provide useful information for investors. Reconciliations of those non-GAAP measures to GAAP can be found in our earnings press release and on the Investors page at www.drpeppersnapple.com.
This morning's prepared remarks will be made by Larry Young, President and CEO; and Marty Ellen, our CFO. Following our prepared remarks, we will open the call for your questions. With that, I'll turn the call over to Larry.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Heather, and good morning, everyone. Our third quarter results continue to demonstrate progress in our strategic initiatives. We stayed focused against our strategy of driving integrated communication and execution across our priority, trademark b
componenttext:
Thanks, Heather, and good morning, everyone. Our third quarter results continue to demonstrate progress in our strategic initiatives. We stayed focused against our strategy of driving integrated communication and execution across our priority, trademark brands, and it is driving good results. We continue to expense growth in the quarter from our allied brand partnerships, and we continue to build our culture of continuous improvement with meaningful results.
For the quarter, bottler case sales increased 2% on 3 points of positive mix and price. CSD volumes increased by 2% and noncarbs were flat. Brand Dr Pepper increased 1% in the quarter as we experienced continued strong growth in our fountain foodservice business as well as growth in our bottled can business. Regular Dr Pepper continued to perform well, and Diet Dr Pepper continued to significantly outperform the diet category, growing by almost 1% in the quarter.
Our Core 4 brands increased 2%, as 7% growth in Canada Dry and 1% growth in Sunkist were partially offset by a 2% decline in A&W and a 1% decline in 7UP. Many of you know that we have had a lean track solely focus on 7UP, and we are encouraged by the results this past quarter.
Crush and Schweppes grew 4% and 9%, respectively, and Squirt grew 7% on strong growth in both Mexico and the U.S. Peñafiel grew 1% in the face of increased competition, particularly against our age lime. All other CSDs decreased 3% in the quarter.
In noncarbs, Snapple was flat, cycling 5% growth a year ago. Hawaiian Punch decreased 6% in the quarter on decreased promotional activity and single-serve price increases. And Mott's declined 6% as well as category headwinds driving declines in juice more than offset growth from our sauce business.
Clamato grew 5% in the quarter, and our water category grew 16% on growth in our allied brand portfolio, particularly Bai and FIJI and continued growth in Aguafiel. We chose to acquire our Aguafiel partnership interest in Mexico rather than liquidate the venture because we believe that on our own, we can further improve the performance of the brand.
All other noncarb brands decreased 9% in the quarter, almost entirely due to our exit of the Country Time business. This decline was partially offset by strong growth in BODYARMOR, another allied brand which is continuing to grow share in the sports drink category.
Unlocking growth in our priority brands through strong communication continues to be critical to driving our business results. Our marketing calendar for the balance of the year and the increased marquee investment in the third quarter reflects just that. We're in the heart of college football season, and once again, Dr Pepper is front and center. We've got heavy media across both TV and several digital platforms and increased activation at retail year-over-year.
New this year, Larry Culpepper will be tailgating across the country in his own Dr Pepper brand to bring the brand to countless football gatherings. In fact, Larry has become such a popular icon to the brand that we began selling Larry Culpepper Halloween costumes this year, and to no surprise, they were sold out in a matter of weeks. We've even spotted a few being listed on eBay for $75 a piece. And in just 2 days, we'll be taking over student sections by feeding the Larry costumes across a multitude of college campuses during the games.
Also new this year, 7UP and Canada Dry will be on both on TV and digital platforms during the holiday season, supporting our green bottle program. And Core 4 is bringing back Monster-themed mini cans for Halloween with an app that will bring the monsters to life on your smart device. We'll continue to drive retail activation against Schweppes sparkling waters honing in on the mixer occasion for the holidays. And Snapple is reminding consumers to take a break from the election with TEAcision, our Red and Blue Fruit election-themed LTO. I think you can see our marketing calendar ends this year very strong.
Now I'll turn the call over to Marty to walk you through our financial results and our updated guidance.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Larry. Good morning, everyone. I'll start by providing a high-level financial summary for the quarter. Sales volume increased 1% with reported net sales up 3%. On a currency-neutral basis, net sales were up 4%. Core operating income was up 5%, and
componenttext:
Thanks, Larry. Good morning, everyone. I'll start by providing a high-level financial summary for the quarter. Sales volume increased 1% with reported net sales up 3%. On a currency-neutral basis, net sales were up 4%. Core operating income was up 5%, and core operating margin was 21.7%, up 40 basis points. Core EPS was up 8% in the quarter, and it was up 9% on a currency-neutral basis.
Now let me provide some further details. Reported net sales increase included 2 points of favorable product and package mix, 1 percentage point of price realization and a 1% increase in sales volumes. Reducing this net sales growth was 1 point of foreign currency translation.
Reported gross margins increased 60 basis points in the quarter, increasing from 58.7% last year to 59.3% this year. 70 basis points of this improvement was driven by the favorable comparison of unrealized mark-to-market commodity price changes. Positive net pricing, including a favorable trade spend adjustment on our Packaged Beverages segment, increased gross margins by 50 basis points.
Lower commodity costs and continued productivity benefits, including those from RCI as well as certain other input cost reductions, increased gross margins by 30 basis points each. The impact of mix, mostly from our allied brands, as expected, reduced gross margins by 80 basis points. And inflationary increases in certain other manufacturing costs and increased depreciation decreased gross margins by 30 basis points.
Finally, foreign currency reduced gross margins in the quarter by 20 basis points, principally as Mexico sources certain inputs in U.S. dollars.
For the quarter, reported SG&A, excluding depreciation, rose by $11 million after a $6 million foreign currency translation benefit. Marketing, as planned, increased $15 million, reflecting new priority brand creatives across several of our trademarks. While we did experience certain other inflationary cost increases, these were mostly offset by lower transportation costs driven by lower fuel prices.
Depreciation and amortization declined $2 million. Other income increased by $5 million as a result of a noncash gain on the step-acquisition accounting of our Aguafiel joint venture in Mexico. We chose to acquire our partner's interest for $15 million, funded with cash in the joint venture.
Below the operating line, net interest expense increased $4 million, primarily reflecting an overall higher debt balance and higher rates from our fourth quarter 2015 refinancing. Our reported effective tax rate was 29.7% in the quarter and includes a $17 million gain associated with a legal entity restructuring. Reported effective tax rate in the prior year was 34.4%.
Moving on to cash flow. Cash from operating activities was $683 million, down $40 million compared to last year, primarily due to the $35 million payment of the multiemployer pension plan liability. Capital spending was $110 million compared to $71 million last year. For the first 9 months, total distributions to our shareholders were $748 million with $460 million in shares repurchased and $288 million in dividends paid.
Before I move on to guidance, let me give a quick update on RCI. You've heard me mention many times that we not only utilized the tools and principles of RCI to drive productivity but also to drive top line growth. Our 2016 lean tracks reflect the balance of the 2 and tackled several of our largest identified opportunities across the organization, and to date, we're seeing strong successes. For example, our web sales team recently refined the void reporting process and closed 98% of their execution voids across regular Dr Pepper smaller CSD packages.
With regard to our allied brand portfolio. An SKU prioritization lean activity resulted in distribution and availability growth on priority SKUs by 42%. Our lean track focused on improving processes affecting our route delivery drivers drove a 17% reduction in turn over year-on-year during the summer selling season. And our lost time injuries are down 32% year-on-year, showing a significant improvement in the most severe injuries as a result of our relentless focus on safety and development of our safety playbooks.
And as I mentioned last quarter, we've been very focused on improving the performance of 7UP and have a separate lean track dedicated to the brand. While we are not declaring success and still have a great deal of work to do on the brand, we are very encouraged by the recent improvement in trends. As you can see, we continue to engage our people across all 5 pillars of RCI: Safety, quality, delivery, productivity and growth.
Now moving to our updated 2016 guidance. We continue to expect reported net sales to be up approximately 2%, inclusive of a foreign currency translation headwind of about 1%. Given our year-to-date performance, we are increasing our full year core EPS guidance. We now expect core EPS to be in the range of $4.32 to $4.40. This is still inclusive of an expected 3% headwind from both foreign currency translation and transaction combined. We continue to expect total company sales volume to be about flat, with CSDs about flat and noncarbs up slightly. We also continue to expect combined price and mix to be up about 3%.
Moving on to cost of goods. We continue to expect packaging and ingredients to be about 1% deflationary on a constant volume/mix basis, which has already been realized. For modeling purposes, remember that growth from some of our noncarb portfolio and allied brands will also increase the dollar value of cost of goods. And also remember that cost of goods is negatively impacted by foreign currency transaction as I mentioned a moment ago. Collectively, all the factors I just mentioned should result in roughly similar gross margins for all of 2016.
Moving to SG&A. We now expect an increase of approximately $5 million in health and welfare and other insurance costs versus the $15 million that we had previously expected, and we have already experienced this increase. We also still expect general inflation in our field labor costs to increase operating expenses by approximately $20 million for the year. We also continue to invest in execution across our business and are forecasting additional investment of about $3 million in our frontline employees in the fourth quarter. That said, we believe we will be able to achieve productivity benefits from RCI that will help offset a portion of these increases, and we continue to expect favorability from lower fuel costs. We continue to expect marketing to be about 7.5% of sales for the full year, which implies an increase in the fourth quarter.
Now moving below segment operating profit, our net interest expense will be approximately $12 million higher, driven primarily by our fourth quarter 2015 debt refinancing.
Our full year core tax rate is now expected to be approximately 35%, and we continue to expect capital spending to be approximately 3% of net sales, including the spending for our new plant in Mexico. We also continue to expect to repurchase approximately $650 million to $700 million of our common stock in 2016, subject to market conditions.
With that, let me turn the call back over to Larry.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marty. Before we open the lines for questions, let me leave you with a few thoughts. We continue to drive strong results across the business. We're focused on driving aligned communication and execution across our priority brands while also select
componenttext:
Thanks, Marty. Before we open the lines for questions, let me leave you with a few thoughts. We continue to drive strong results across the business. We're focused on driving aligned communication and execution across our priority brands while also selectively adding to our allied brand portfolio in an effort to compete in fast-growing categories. We're continuing to embed RCI further into our culture. And importantly, we remain committed to returning excess free cash to our shareholders over time.
Operator, we're ready for our first question.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Dara Mohsenian of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Dara Mohsenian of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in the past, you guys have sounded fairly skeptical in regards to M&A and your ability to drive shareholder value through acquisition, just given the high multiples in the industry. I was hoping you could just give us a bit of an update on your thought
componenttext: So in the past, you guys have sounded fairly skeptical in regards to M&A and your ability to drive shareholder value through acquisition, just given the high multiples in the industry. I was hoping you could just give us a bit of an update on your thoughts on M&A, if anything has changed in your thinking, particularly given we've seen a number of high-growth companies, both in your allied portfolio as well as outside, sustained success over time, so maybe that makes you bit more comfortable with industry valuation levels. But I was just hoping for an update there.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dara, it's Marty. I'll make some comments, and Larry can add anything if he wants. So obviously, this question goes to directly one of the things we've talked about in terms of risk on our allied brand portfolio is what happens when and if one of these br
componenttext: Dara, it's Marty. I'll make some comments, and Larry can add anything if he wants. So obviously, this question goes to directly one of the things we've talked about in terms of risk on our allied brand portfolio is what happens when and if one of these brand owners decide to sell their brand. I think we're really comfortable with the strategy itself and the ability of us through allied brand partners to move quickly with the consumer to innovate quickly and to do it in a way, at least at the front end that requires little hard capital. It does require work to execute. You know clearly, we've always said that it's not about if it's more about when the successful ones decide and want to do something with their companies. These are all start-ups. These are all entrepreneurial great businesses. And you know our view is whatever we do, whatever we should do is going to be done in a disciplined way. And you mentioned, Dara, something just now, don't sit around awhile, know that there are a handful of precedent transactions in this industry that I think we would all characterize having been done at very large multiples. Everyone conformed their own conclusion. I think you know some of those brands whether or not made hindsight those ended up being successful or not. But we want to be very disciplined. You know that -- those precedent transactions clearly drive many entrepreneurs to do exactly what they are going to be creative, to innovate, and we like that, and we're partnered with a number of them. And a number of these brands are showing some very early signs of success. Now we can't and are not in control of what these brand owners decide they want to do with their companies when they want to do it, how they want to do it. I think, look, fair to say as a major distributor of these brands, we would be aware if something were happening. But look, and we also understand that whether or not the very high levels of early growth could be sustained over a long enough period of time obviously carries risks. Whether or not brands that start in a certain category can actually be extendable early in their life to other categories is challengeable. And so we're mindful of this, and we never forget about competition. You've seen plenty of examples in different categories. When others see somebody being successful, you draw a competition, and we know we've seen explosions in categories. You can look to sparkling water for example. Look where that is today versus where it was. Thankfully, the category still growing strongly. So we think about all these things carefully. We will never say never, but we're going to be careful and cautious.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. And then the second question is I was hoping you could just give us an update on the pricing environment of what you're seeing in the marketplace for a promotional and less pricing standpoint. And as we look going forward, if commodit
componenttext: That's very helpful. And then the second question is I was hoping you could just give us an update on the pricing environment of what you're seeing in the marketplace for a promotional and less pricing standpoint. And as we look going forward, if commodities do reinflate, do you think you'll be in a position to offset higher commodities with additional pricing? Or is the current run rate more of a normalized level even if commodities reinflate? And last, just can you just touch on how hedged you are for inputs as you look out to 2017?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll take the first part of that. I think everybody have seen pricing has been very disciplined. We're not seeing anything out in the market that gives us any angst. It's very disciplined. It's very thought out how the promotions are being ran. I think pr
componenttext: I'll take the first part of that. I think everybody have seen pricing has been very disciplined. We're not seeing anything out in the market that gives us any angst. It's very disciplined. It's very thought out how the promotions are being ran. I think promotional activity, of course, this time of year always steps up a little bit with the holidays. And I think where the pricing is today if we saw any movement in commodities, I mean, we still have to look at it and say we go where the market is. We have to be competitive. And so you know, as we've always told you in the past, we don't always put a lot in their own pricing.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on the part of the question that goes to hedging, we're in a similar position to where we've been in prior years for '17 at this time of the year. So we think we're in a good position going into '17. We'll obviously give more color on that and cost of
componenttext: And on the part of the question that goes to hedging, we're in a similar position to where we've been in prior years for '17 at this time of the year. So we think we're in a good position going into '17. We'll obviously give more color on that and cost of goods trends when we talk on our February call.

It seems to be a bit low in our add. So I mean could you give us a bit more color about your quarter 4 forecast?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Look, needless to say, we have all year run ahead of what we had been guiding. We've always been cautious roundabout category, and everybody knows where CSDs are. Yes, we have performed better, and we're particularly pleased with the recent result f
componenttext: Sure. Look, needless to say, we have all year run ahead of what we had been guiding. We've always been cautious roundabout category, and everybody knows where CSDs are. Yes, we have performed better, and we're particularly pleased with the recent result for Dr Pepper and even more so 7UP. But oh, by the way, we also in the past had a lot of growth from our lead brand, I would call our lead brand in Mexico, Peñafiel. That's really now not unexpected from strong double-digit growth. So you know, we tend to regress a little bit back closer to certain category trend, but I will acknowledge that we've overachieved against those for the first 9 months of this year.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 quick questions. One is just looking at that Canada Dry numbers, I mean it's been on a tear. Just wanted to get some perspective on what you think is driving that, whether it be just consumer preferences or if there's something specific happening a
componenttext: Just 2 quick questions. One is just looking at that Canada Dry numbers, I mean it's been on a tear. Just wanted to get some perspective on what you think is driving that, whether it be just consumer preferences or if there's something specific happening at retail? And then the second question is on Monster Mutant. I've noticed that it showed up in some of the Dr Pepper Snapple Group shelf slots at a couple of retailers. And so I just wanted to get your thoughts around that. Is that kind of part of the plan? Or this is something that you're trying to combat because I know there's some issues right now with spacing in Pepsi with that product?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll answer on the Canada Dry. I'm probably not going to touch the second one there. On Canada Dry, I mean if you look at the ginger ale category, it's doing fantastic. And so we're the leader in that category, and we put together a lot of new media.
componenttext: Yes, I'll answer on the Canada Dry. I'm probably not going to touch the second one there. On Canada Dry, I mean if you look at the ginger ale category, it's doing fantastic. And so we're the leader in that category, and we put together a lot of new media. You know we went through our return on margin investment. We know which way to advertise now, whether it's shorter television or more going towards the digital and where to play in digital. Then, of course, our consumer-centric strategy is telling us where that consumer is. And we're listening to the consumer. We want the occasion, and we're there. We have the product there. So you're correct. It's on a tear, and we expect it to continue that way.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Larry, I guess I wanted to drill a little bit into your noncarb performance. Certainly the CSD being up 2%, it's been a positive trend. The noncarbs being flattish is sort of in contrast to some of the other companies that have shown better noncarb gro
componenttext: So Larry, I guess I wanted to drill a little bit into your noncarb performance. Certainly the CSD being up 2%, it's been a positive trend. The noncarbs being flattish is sort of in contrast to some of the other companies that have shown better noncarb growth. So can you just drill into sort of what's happening within your noncarb portfolio? And then if you exclude allied brands, what would your noncarb growth have been, so just kind of thinking about the noncarb strategy?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, Judy, if you go back to my prepared remarks, it's all driven by Mott's and Hawaiian Punch. Mott's, the juice category, is a category that's facing headwinds there. So we're not surprised with that. We had great growth with our sauce but not
componenttext: Yes, I think, Judy, if you go back to my prepared remarks, it's all driven by Mott's and Hawaiian Punch. Mott's, the juice category, is a category that's facing headwinds there. So we're not surprised with that. We had great growth with our sauce but not enough to overcome what we had on the juice decline. Hawaiian Punch was a conscious decision. We took pricing. That category too has got some headwinds, but we took pricing, and they are especially on our single-serve, and that drove it. You take those 2 out. And like Marty said earlier, our allied brands, again, were continuing to grow about the same as last quarter. Snapple was flat this quarter, but it was again some activity we had last year, and we got some activity coming up now that I mentioned that's going to reverse that. So it will be coming back up. So those 2 are the only 2 that really drove that. So it wasn't a surprise to us. We consciously took the pricing on Hawaiian Punch, and I think we'll see -- hopefully, we'll see some improvement next quarter.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. And then, Marty, just a quick follow-up. So one is just the favorable trade accrual adjustment that you called out in Packaged Beverages. Can you quantify how much that helped the price mix?
componenttext: Okay, got it. And then, Marty, just a quick follow-up. So one is just the favorable trade accrual adjustment that you called out in Packaged Beverages. Can you quantify how much that helped the price mix?

componenttext: Yes, it was in the range of -- I think it was about $5 million or short number. Not an uncommon adjustment for us as we go back and true-up our trade spend estimates versus what actually came in, in terms of actual program cost. This happens from time to time. It was about $5 million.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay. And then for the full year guidance, so obviously, the sales and the cost of goods component don't seem to have changed. So when you sort of bridge from the prior earnings guidance to the current guidance, it seems like most of the drivers rea
componenttext: Okay, okay. And then for the full year guidance, so obviously, the sales and the cost of goods component don't seem to have changed. So when you sort of bridge from the prior earnings guidance to the current guidance, it seems like most of the drivers really on health care costs coming in lower, maybe a little bit of a tax rate being more favorable. And then on the marketing side, it sounds like you're still kind of favorable year-to-date. So $90 million, I think, reduction in the first half and $60 million in the third quarter. So should we expect the fourth quarter to see another kind of step-up in terms of the marketing?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, Judy, in marketing, absolutely. We've not -- the timing during the year, as I think you know and everybody knows, was all about us basically going back and redoing lot of our trademark creative to align with all the work we did in the
componenttext: Well, first of all, Judy, in marketing, absolutely. We've not -- the timing during the year, as I think you know and everybody knows, was all about us basically going back and redoing lot of our trademark creative to align with all the work we did in the prior year on our consumer-centric strategy. We will have an increase in marketing for the year. It's going to be in the back half. You saw $15 million or so of it in this quarter, and you're going to see another increase in the fourth quarter. So we like our marketing plans. We like what we're doing, and we think it's actually contributing quite a bit to our top line improvement. So in terms of the guidance, yes, there are somethings this quarter that fell through. You had mentioned the tax rate, our tax rate driven by that gain on the joint venture that was a nontaxable gain. That flows through. I'll remind you also that earlier in the year we settled an arbitration award that was awarded against us, also related to that joint venture. So yes, I mean, we've not -- we've flowed through a few of those things, and otherwise, we're sort of where we are.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question has to do with Diets. Clearly, an exceptional results on Diet Dr Pepper. So I was hoping you could offer a little color on some of the activity in the quarter as well as your view of the diet category as a whole, dare to dream, are the d
componenttext: My first question has to do with Diets. Clearly, an exceptional results on Diet Dr Pepper. So I was hoping you could offer a little color on some of the activity in the quarter as well as your view of the diet category as a whole, dare to dream, are the declines actually easing? Are we finding a floor here in terms of the diet consumer?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think we've seen the decline in the category slow down a little bit. I think some of that's been driven by what we've been doing. You know as we've mentioned in the previous quarter, I mean, we continue to market, especially our Dr Pepper, with the
componenttext: No, I think we've seen the decline in the category slow down a little bit. I think some of that's been driven by what we've been doing. You know as we've mentioned in the previous quarter, I mean, we continue to market, especially our Dr Pepper, with the Lil' Sweet. We've seen a great return on that, and you saw the numbers. I mean, we're up almost 1% for the third quarter. We also go out to them. We talked about our execution. We make sure that as we try to keep our brands top of mind and the great taste of our diets that they're also close at hand. So execution in the field has been good. So we're pleased with what we're seeing and happen with our diets.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just a follow-up on that. Any insight in terms of kind of consumer sentiment around the category? More broadly, clearly, you guys are bucking the trend. But is there kind of a broader read there?
componenttext: And just a follow-up on that. Any insight in terms of kind of consumer sentiment around the category? More broadly, clearly, you guys are bucking the trend. But is there kind of a broader read there?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know, I wish I could read it. There's so many choices out there today. I think that, that diet drinker has many, many more choices than they used to have. I think we're keeping ours top of mind so that we're trying to keep them in there. You know I th
componenttext: You know, I wish I could read it. There's so many choices out there today. I think that, that diet drinker has many, many more choices than they used to have. I think we're keeping ours top of mind so that we're trying to keep them in there. You know I think the -- we all know the consumer is looking at a lot of different products right now, but I think as they -- you know they switch around. They still want that great taste. Taste is still everything.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I know it's not fair. So we didn't sort of give you a pass last quarter on the weather. But is there any way you can sort of dimensionalize how much the favorable weather impacted the results this quarter?
componenttext: I know it's not fair. So we didn't sort of give you a pass last quarter on the weather. But is there any way you can sort of dimensionalize how much the favorable weather impacted the results this quarter?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. You know, we really haven't had the -- I can't think of any place that we've had weather that would be enough to make a change in a trend. It's been a little bit warmer. But whenever you get to certain parts of the country, when it gets warmer, they g
componenttext: No. You know, we really haven't had the -- I can't think of any place that we've had weather that would be enough to make a change in a trend. It's been a little bit warmer. But whenever you get to certain parts of the country, when it gets warmer, they get concerned because there's no rain. They'd rather have the rain. They'd rather have the colder weather, especially the Midwest. So we don't really pay that much attention to the weather because there's nothing we can do about it. We still have to execute and deliver. I know Rodger. I've heard he tell his guys that he doesn't heard weatherman that we get after no matter what the weather is. So I don't believe it was significant, Bill.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. No, that's fair. And then can you just give me a little more color on the allied brand business, like why people choose you guys over the other options in the market? And if there's any interest in new allied brands in the pipeline? And then just la
componenttext: Okay. No, that's fair. And then can you just give me a little more color on the allied brand business, like why people choose you guys over the other options in the market? And if there's any interest in new allied brands in the pipeline? And then just lastly, I think there's like change of control provisions. So if someone else did come in and buy like a brand like Bai, I think that the sort of industry metric is you get 2 years of gross profit or something, if it change the distribution. Is that still the case?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll take the first part of that, Bill, and let Marty take it. I mean you've heard us say before, we had a tremendous pipeline of allied brands that come to us that we can look at. And they have to fit certain criteria. Just kind of remind you, I mean if
componenttext: I'll take the first part of that, Bill, and let Marty take it. I mean you've heard us say before, we had a tremendous pipeline of allied brands that come to us that we can look at. And they have to fit certain criteria. Just kind of remind you, I mean if you look at our total allied brands are only about 5% of our volume. You know there's several large players in there. I mean it's not big volume, but it's 5% of our total. And you know we have an open system. I mean, our distribution system is open to brands that fit our strategy. I don't know if the other people out there with relative markets in DSD allow that flexibility. So it makes it a natural form to come to us, which is fantastic because we can look and see what is the trend. We know what our consumers are looking for, and so we can make sure we have the right customers that come in or the right partners on an allied brand. Then I'll let Marty take the rest of it.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Bill, it's -- we believe, from our own strategy and feedback from consumers, that many of our brands are not extendable from their current space. Dr Pepper is an indulgent occasion. Our consumers said, don't try to make the Dr Pepper better for me, ch
componenttext: And Bill, it's -- we believe, from our own strategy and feedback from consumers, that many of our brands are not extendable from their current space. Dr Pepper is an indulgent occasion. Our consumers said, don't try to make the Dr Pepper better for me, changing the formulation, changing the sweetener system, but yet consumers are at times do want to have a better-for-you occasion. And that's where the growth is, and that's, as I said earlier, there's lots of incentive for start-ups and entrepreneurs to want to go there, to see the opportunity. And when they come to us, I think I've shared with all of you, we have a pretty rigid checklist of requirements that pass through the gates here in terms of the brand, the strategy, how they see the consumer versus our consumer insights, the credibility of the management team, their access to capital. We do not want to fund these businesses early on and yet they have to have the capital to do what the bran downer needs to do early on, particularly in sales and marketing. And you know, look, I'll tell you the pipeline is pretty full. And many times, we talk about limiting how many we want to actually get serious with, just simply because we worry about our ability to execute too many in too short a time frame. It's an interesting list of products that are in the energy space and, obviously, the enhanced water space, maple syrup or something water, I'm not sure what that even is. So I don't look for anything soon coming out of us on that, but I know it's on the list somewhere. You see all these brands. You'll see them from time to time in various places in the markets, particularly in New York. And so we like this path. We like this path to innovation.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Marty, you brought up a really key point on making sure that we can execute what we do bring in. I mean, we work very, very closely with our allied partners. I mean, we feel like they're a part of the company. I mean, we work our plans together. To Ma
componenttext: And Marty, you brought up a really key point on making sure that we can execute what we do bring in. I mean, we work very, very closely with our allied partners. I mean, we feel like they're a part of the company. I mean, we work our plans together. To Marty's point, they're doing the marketing. We've got to do the execution. And so it has to be hand in hand. And so we don't want to just take everything that comes in and let some things fall through the crack. Pick up what we're going to do and then execute it with excellence.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just the tail end of that question was, I mean, the way you typically protect yourself, and I don't need specifics, but isn't it typically like the rule of thumb you get a couple of years of gross profit back if they break distribution, if
componenttext: Okay. And then just the tail end of that question was, I mean, the way you typically protect yourself, and I don't need specifics, but isn't it typically like the rule of thumb you get a couple of years of gross profit back if they break distribution, if they get a new buyer. Is that a good assumption to use?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not going to share specifically what we negotiate in these contracts other than to say that in our view, it's a reasonably strong payment to us to compensate us for the value that we helped create.
componenttext: I'm not going to share specifically what we negotiate in these contracts other than to say that in our view, it's a reasonably strong payment to us to compensate us for the value that we helped create.

componenttext: Just following on the allied brands briefly, I assume your -- the distribution partner just in the places where you company-own the bottling. Is that right?

componenttext: That's correct.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And would you, in theory, if you were to lose one of your bigger brands, would you make a concerted effort to quickly replace that volume? Or is that not how you think about it?
componenttext: And would you, in theory, if you were to lose one of your bigger brands, would you make a concerted effort to quickly replace that volume? Or is that not how you think about it?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely.
componenttext: Absolutely.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You would.
componenttext: You would.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. We've done it in the past. This is not a new strategy for us. We've had allied brands for a long time. We've just refined it in the last few years. We've lost some major players, and we've built them back. We hate to lose them, but we also und
componenttext: Absolutely. We've done it in the past. This is not a new strategy for us. We've had allied brands for a long time. We've just refined it in the last few years. We've lost some major players, and we've built them back. We hate to lose them, but we also understand sometimes why they sell. And we're always involved. When they are for sale, as Marty said earlier, we know it, and we're their partner. So we're always observing. But you know sometimes you lose them, and then you have to go out and make it back. And I think we've been very successful to build on that. We've lost Rockstar. We've lost Monster. We lost Vitaminwater. We lost Fuse. And we continue to go. We keep building our allied brand portfolio.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. The retail climate right now, Larry, if you could just comment on what you're seeing with shelf space movement. One thing I'm wondering about is because the cola, diet cola seems to be much more vulnerable than other categories. Are you seeing oppo
componenttext: Right. The retail climate right now, Larry, if you could just comment on what you're seeing with shelf space movement. One thing I'm wondering about is because the cola, diet cola seems to be much more vulnerable than other categories. Are you seeing opportunities for more shelf space from cola or diet cola would you say?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we really haven't seen any of that. Even with the diets, of course, our competitors, we're going to fight for their space, and they're going to have LTOs and innovation and other things they could put in there. So we're not really picking up any, but
componenttext: No, we really haven't seen any of that. Even with the diets, of course, our competitors, we're going to fight for their space, and they're going to have LTOs and innovation and other things they could put in there. So we're not really picking up any, but we're also not losing. So we're very happy with that. Everybody wants more space, but it's very, very expensive real estate out there in a supermarket.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And in the food service, you're doing quite well, yet we're hearing restaurant traffic is down a lot. So do you think you're just gaining share? Or it's not the restaurants you sell to, given [indiscernible]?
componenttext: And in the food service, you're doing quite well, yet we're hearing restaurant traffic is down a lot. So do you think you're just gaining share? Or it's not the restaurants you sell to, given [indiscernible]?

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're getting new availability. We're gaining some share, and we're seeing QSRs up slightly, up about 1%, and so I think that helped some, but our teams does a fabulous job of going out there and getting new valves, getting more availability. As I m
componenttext: Well, we're getting new availability. We're gaining some share, and we're seeing QSRs up slightly, up about 1%, and so I think that helped some, but our teams does a fabulous job of going out there and getting new valves, getting more availability. As I mentioned earlier, I mean, that's one of the reasons our diets are doing well, and we're having a huge push on diet in the fountain because if we're out there doing marketing and we're top of mind, we have to have it close at hand. If you're going to be drinking it at work, at play and while you're dining, that's what you'll buy and take home with you.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Got it. And then one for Marty, please, and then I'm done. But the $5 million accrual reversal, does most of that go to the bottom line?
